number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Similar to Minecraft but in a pixelized 2D platformer style. However there are feautures in this game that set both apart, making it not a game competition but instead a player preferrence. Anyway, here's a brief analysis about Terraria:- You can build a house, a bunker, a hut, a castle, a village, a tower, a base, a farm, a floating island or whatever you have in mind by placing the blocks and the furniture you want. There are so many different blocks that some people even make pixel drawings with them.- You can gather resources, such as mining for ores, chop wood, harvest hay, pick plants (and yet you can make a farm of them), catch critters, and even fishing.- You can smelt, mix or craft new items (materials, gear, weapons, potions, acessories, objects, blocks, food, furniture, etc) based on the resources you've gathered or even from other materials. You can also paint blocks/walls or dye your equipment. You literally have thousands of different items.- There are many different types of weapons: swords, axes, hammers, pickaxes, spears, flails, yoyos, boomerangs, bows, guns, crossbows, throwables, wands, spell tomes, summoning weapons, and few others. These weapons are distincted by dealing melee, ranged or magic damage.- You can ride through minecarts, summon pets and ride mounts.- There are hundreds of different enemies, most of them are located in their specific biomes or in a specific weather/day condition, some even drop some specific rare items (some are even essential for crafting). There are also bosses that appear only in specific biomes.- There are some events that might catch you by surprise. It may happen enemy invasions (like a goblin army or even aliens) or invasions based on odd moon phases (like Blood Moon or Solar Eclipse). NPCs (villagers) will get different behaviours based on the day/night cycle or lunar phases (like a NPC selling certain items during a certain part of the day or female NPCs speaking agressively during Blood Moon).- With the proper accessories, you can fly and/or double-jump in action. (note that there is no Creative mode nor Spectator mode in Terraria, however it has a Camera Mode)- Biomes are not that static as it seems. Some can expand on the dirt/mud, some can even corrupt other biomes to become part of their own (via dirt, stone and even sand) and spawn unwanted enemies while making impossible for your NPCs to live in (which is one of the many challenges in this game, some players tend to extinct these kind of biomes to preserve other biomes or their villages).- There are a certain type of difficuly settings that you can put when making a character (softcore, mediumcore or hardcore aka permadeath) or generating a map (you can set it to Expert mode where it alters enemy stats, drops, loot, spawns, buffs, death penalizations, etc). However, after defeating a boss called "Wall of Flesh", you'll enter on what will be called as "Hardmode". From this point on many new (and yet stronger) enemies will spawn on each biome, new yet more valuable ores will randomly appear, new random events might happen, enemies may drop new items, biomes that tend to corrupt will corrupt faster, you can procceed to new yet stronger bosses, new NPCs (villagers) can be found while current ones can sell new items, and many new items to loot.- You have the Multiplayer feauture. You can host or join a server via IP address, or you can easily invite/join your friends directly via Steam, which quite fun when fighting bosses. In Multiplayer you can also join a team (red, blue, green, yellow, etc), so you can kill and loot a player from the opposite team or even do a "Capture the Gem" match. Overall, I'll give it a 9/10. Despite not having an infinite map, the whole map itself is very rich when it comes to resources, mobs, caves and loot.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												After reaching 800 hours, I think it's about time I wrote a review of this game. I've restarted my terraria save countless times over and I have never found an end to the joy I get it. Terraria offers it's own unique and thrilling experience the further you get into the game, whether it's spamming shurikens and knives at bosses, to picking away at ore pockets in the caverns and even just going about your stroll over to the oceon. Recently, I got playing this game again with a friend of mine, early on they kept asking 'when's the fun part?'. Once we actually had semi-decent gear, she finally said 'Oh yea, this part's pretty fun'. Long story short, keeping new friends to the game is a struggle but rewarding, best times are on expert mode where you can start ♥♥♥♥♥ing about who gets what and framing♥♥♥♥♥♥on each other.With the updates that game with this game such as the chaotic madness of 1.3, they've brought so much more to treat yourself with, and makes all the effort and time much more rewarding. How about the sountrack? There isn't a single decibel that i could complain about, it adds to the ambience and atomsphere of every level making the game even harder to leave.I took a look at the achievments and the percentage of people who've earnt them and I feel that not enough people are reaching these exciting components of the late game. People either than out of time or interest in the game and move on.  I can definately assue you that the game is worth every single penny.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												This has to be one of my favorite games on Steam. There is so much to do and collect that at this point, I don't think I'll ever be able to find every item. Terraria has great replayability and since your characters can visit any world, it allows you to begin anew without losing your progress. I've set up a gigantic storage world so I can horde every item and block I've ever collected and my collection continues to grow. But out of all this, the best part of Terraria is co-op.Since the game progression is fast paced, you can start a game with a friend and reach end-game in about a week or sooner depending on how long you play for. Co-op really works well in this game mainly because the fighting style. Spelunking with a friend is always safer especially once you plunge into hardmode. And the boss fights are a blast with more people.The environments and random terrain generation create beautiful environments to explore. The textures and lighting fit perfectly together and the unique game music is the icing on the cake.So basically what I'm trying to say is: I love this game! I've put a ridiculous amount of time into Terraria and I even feel that the game is worth way more than the full price.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												This game is super fun and will give you a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of hours of game play. With the never ending updates and mods that comes out there will always be something new to discover.  You can play alone or with friends and still enjoy it just at much. The survival, sandbox and crafting is perfectly combined. Enemies are hard until you get better gear. And you will always have a hard time against your next boss. The game is paced perfectly, because of this you won’t get tiered from playing it too much. It might be a bit hard to find out how things work without googling. But it makes the game still fun to play. It’s not too much grinding after thing, maybe I just got lucky with everything. You never feel like there is nothing to do. There is always something cool to build or a boss that you need to kill. The cool thing is you can build your own boss arenas where you can build defensive walls and traps. With the statues and some wiring you can build some really cool and creative stuff. And mods even add more to that. You have the chance to build fully automatic machines that can farm things for you. The further into the game you get the more diverse the armours and weapons get. So if you want to be a wizard you can get your magic gear and if you want to be a warrior you can build the tanker gear. In the beginning there is less of this which makes the game easier to understand and you will have something new to learn while you get into the late game. With every update adding a lot of hours of new content you always want more. There is no stopping the need for more. It’s like an addiction. The game is very cheap and every update is completely free which is why the developers are very loved by the community. The game got released in 2011 and still get very big updates.Something I used to get really annoyed at in the past was the lack of endgame weapons for each class. The summoner really didn’t have any good end game weapon. The best weapon was a melee weapon, it had the highest DPS. But all of this is fixed with the latest update giving all 4 different classes their own type of end game weapon, and not only 1 for every class. E.g. there are 3 different melee end game weapons. They have different effects and use but usually the same DPS depending on how you use them and what gear you have.The developers really take in feedback from the community and mould the game after it. If you have tips for future updates just leave them in the forum and someone from the development team will probably read it. This really makes this game great. If there is something that does not work after an update the fix is probably going to be out in just a couple of days.

												Crafting, exploring, or fighting, whatever you choose player freedom is at the center of it all. It's up to you what you do in this world and that's what makes it so fun. Mining for new materials is a blast, and the more you find the more you can create. You can also tackle the various enemies about and hunt down some great bosses. number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Similar to Minecraft but in a pixelized 2D platformer style. However there are feautures in this game that set both apart, making it not a game competition but instead a player preferrence. Anyway, here's a brief analysis about Terraria:- You can build a house, a bunker, a hut, a castle, a village, a tower, a base, a farm, a floating island or whatever you have in mind by placing the blocks and the furniture you want. There are so many different blocks that some people even make pixel drawings with them.- You can gather resources, such as mining for ores, chop wood, harvest hay, pick plants (and yet you can make a farm of them), catch critters, and even fishing.- You can smelt, mix or craft new items (materials, gear, weapons, potions, acessories, objects, blocks, food, furniture, etc) based on the resources you've gathered or even from other materials. You can also paint blocks/walls or dye your equipment. You literally have thousands of different items.- There are many different types of weapons: swords, axes, hammers, pickaxes, spears, flails, yoyos, boomerangs, bows, guns, crossbows, throwables, wands, spell tomes, summoning weapons, and few others. These weapons are distincted by dealing melee, ranged or magic damage.- You can ride through minecarts, summon pets and ride mounts.- There are hundreds of different enemies, most of them are located in their specific biomes or in a specific weather/day condition, some even drop some specific rare items (some are even essential for crafting). There are also bosses that appear only in specific biomes.- There are some events that might catch you by surprise. It may happen enemy invasions (like a goblin army or even aliens) or invasions based on odd moon phases (like Blood Moon or Solar Eclipse). NPCs (villagers) will get different behaviours based on the day/night cycle or lunar phases (like a NPC selling certain items during a certain part of the day or female NPCs speaking agressively during Blood Moon).- With the proper accessories, you can fly and/or double-jump in action. (note that there is no Creative mode nor Spectator mode in Terraria, however it has a Camera Mode)- Biomes are not that static as it seems. Some can expand on the dirt/mud, some can even corrupt other biomes to become part of their own (via dirt, stone and even sand) and spawn unwanted enemies while making impossible for your NPCs to live in (which is one of the many challenges in this game, some players tend to extinct these kind of biomes to preserve other biomes or their villages).- There are a certain type of difficuly settings that you can put when making a character (softcore, mediumcore or hardcore aka permadeath) or generating a map (you can set it to Expert mode where it alters enemy stats, drops, loot, spawns, buffs, death penalizations, etc). However, after defeating a boss called "Wall of Flesh", you'll enter on what will be called as "Hardmode". From this point on many new (and yet stronger) enemies will spawn on each biome, new yet more valuable ores will randomly appear, new random events might happen, enemies may drop new items, biomes that tend to corrupt will corrupt faster, you can procceed to new yet stronger bosses, new NPCs (villagers) can be found while current ones can sell new items, and many new items to loot.- You have the Multiplayer feauture. You can host or join a server via IP address, or you can easily invite/join your friends directly via Steam, which quite fun when fighting bosses. In Multiplayer you can also join a team (red, blue, green, yellow, etc), so you can kill and loot a player from the opposite team or even do a "Capture the Gem" match. Overall, I'll give it a 9/10. Despite not having an infinite map, the whole map itself is very rich when it comes to resources, mobs, caves and loot.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												At first glance, Terraria is reminiscent of its popular 3D counterpart Minecraft. However, underneath its crafting, mining and exploration based surface, lies a game brimming with content and adventure. The game's main concepts revolve around the mining of various resources to craft new weapons and armours, or to design and build houses and structures. This crafting system ties in well with the game's combat and exploration aspects, and gives a greater sense of progression. There're many hidden treasures to be found, along with a multitude of customisation options. The combat is very fast paced and the amount of content featured is astonishing. Would highly recommend to anyone, whether they enjoy building, combat, or just exploring. Terraria's procedurally generated worlds offer endless opporunities and fun.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												After having put quite a few good hours into this game (and still going strong) I can say that it is worth the small price of getting it. Like some people, when I first came into Terraria, I exepcted something of a 2d Minecraft. After spending 40mins trying to figure out how to place a damn door, I realized that this really shouldn't be compared to Minecraft alone. This game feels like something of a hybrid between Minecraft and Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past. Yes, it sounds strange to say that, but considering the items you can get, the boss battles, and the general atmosphere of the game, I feel that is pretty much what Terraria is. That being said, it is unique in a lot of ways and highly worth getting. It may be confusing, difficult, or frusterating at first (I didn't look at the wiki until at least a good 15 hours into it, so that might explain that), but once you pass that hump, it is quite enjoyable. Once again, it's worth getting.

												100% Would recommend this game to anyone.There is so much packed into this game for such a little price;-Hundreds of Enemies and a Variety of Bosses challenge you along your way even if you play on the lightest difficulties each one with a unique attack pattern and style. -Hundreds more Weapons to slay the foes you face varying from a Sword that fires Kittens as you swing, to a Prism that fires a Consentrated beam of Light that Disitigrates the opposition.-Thousands of Unique blocks, Vanity items, Mounts and anything you can really imagine.-A Multitude of ways to play such as a Ranged Bow/Gun-Man, a Warrior, Tank or Mage.-A Host of Events that will challenge you along your adventure and test your skills in survival.-NPC's to accompany you each one with their own Dialogue, Store and Purpose.-Player hosted Public servers so you can make new friends and try new game-modes.There's a lot more I could list but i'd rather you find out for yourself when you play. These are just a few of the reasons why hundreds of hours can come out of a small, yet big, Indie game. =D

												First of all, I just want to press this issue: This is not a minecraft clone, or just "2D Minecraft" honestly, the most similarity they have is the concept of digging, building, and fighting. But it stops there. Even those concepts are so much more different from minecraft. It is a great game, and it has great replay value. 												With the recent update (1.3) adding steam integration which allows multiplayer without hamachi or portforwarding, I can safely say this is a game that should be in everyone's steam library. It's a 2d sandbox adventure that not only has it to where you can craft a bunch of stuff, it also has it to where you fight bosses, loot chests, and a lot of other things that you'd expect in an adventure-sandbox game. number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
OverviewTerraria is a 2D, pixel style, sandbox, survival game with some small RPG elements. You start off in a world where there are various different areas to explore. You can mine, build, explore, and fight bosses. There are many different items you can collect and use to progress through the game.OpinionsThis is an all time favorite of mine. I like how this game combines a sandbox survival with a linear style RPG game. The world is huge, even if you chose "Small World". I like how there are alternatives in the worlds so its not the same thing every time. This adds lots of replayability to the game. The multiplayer is really easy to set up since it has dedicated servers now. The community for this game is huge. There are millions of very loyal fans to this game, and I am definatly one of them. I see this game compared to minecraft alot because of it's art style, genre, and gameplay. Ill admit that there are lots of similarities, but I don't agree with people calling this game a 2D Minecraft. This game has more of an emphisis on linear gameplay, while Minecraft has practically none.RatingsGameplay: 5/5Replayability: 5/5Multiplayer: 5/5Value: 5/5ConclutionEven at full price, this game is a steal. There is so much content and so many different ways to play this game. As of 1.3, the game is pretty much finnished and won't see anymore major updates. But the final thing that develepers are working on is mod support, which will give the game even more replayability than it already has.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												This game is basically a level-up sandbox. You don't actually get levels and stats to increase (except health and mana), but you get stronger via equipment. The point of this game is basically to kill things and obtain certain materials to get stronger and kill more things and find even better materials while finding some cool stuff along the way to build your house or make your house look prettier with.Those who like the level-up aspect are going to enjoy the wide variety of accessories and weapons to mess with. The people who enjoy the sandbox part are going to enjoy building their houses/building with all the different kinds of materials and furnitures.Replay value gets bland after a while. You can make a new character and get more items again (maybe even new items) in your new playthrough, but after a while when you get most of the items and you've beaten all the bosses the game starts getting repetitive and bland. If you're really creative though, you'll probably enjoy the game for a while longer thinking of new things to build.Overall, I like this game, but I think if you're going to get it you should just wait for it to go on sale.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Ahh Terraria, where to begin!Terraria is an excellent example of a (not so) basic sandbox with a sort of RPG mix! With unique art style and sort of new gameplay, Terraria is a great choice for new sandbox/survival gamers. Through my time of playing Terraria, I have found an attachment to the game like no other! The unique weapons and armour, plus the amazing (yet some difficult) monsters you face! Not to add, but the music and sounds for the game add a hint of retroness to the game itself, making this game's soundtrack a taste of my liking :). Not to forget, those spine-chilling boss battles with so much difference between them, a huge challenge for new beginners and great fun for semi-pros to pros. Terraria unfortunately falls a bit short with the reason being that the superb game is only available on Windows computers, meaning Macintosh and Linux users don't get the awesome gameplay that Terraria has to offer. Overall, Terraria is an excellent game with Exciting new bosses, difficult adventurous dungeons, new monsters to battle and a wide variety of awesome stylish weapons plus defence.My rating for Terraria is as followed:Gameplay: 6/10Landscape: 7/10Uniqueness: 9/10Graphics: 8.5/10Fun I Had Playing It!: 8/10Average: 7.7/10Rating: BYours sincerely, Liam

content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												Самым молодым представителем этого нового семейства на данный момент выступает Terraria.Процедурной генерацией разработчики балуются давно. Можно вспомнить всеми любимую Diablo 2, где практически все локации для каждого героя были уникальны. Подземелья, равнины, пустыни и разнообразные пещеры — все это создавала сама игра, найти два одинаковых места было невозможно. Ну, кроме городов и обиталищ сюжетных боссов.Terraria — это ни в коем случае не клон Minecraft. У нее совершенно иная внутренняя философия. Это приключение, не привносящее в жанр ничего нового, но обильно и очень уместно заимствующее чужие идеи. Правда, после того, как будут найдены самые мощные вещи, станет резко скучно.Плюсы: уникальные и интересные миры; огромное количество рецептов и простота крафта; «живой» мультиплеер; приятная пиксельная графика.Минусы: быстро надоедающий саундтрек; завышенная сложность в «сингле»; невозможность начать без дополнительной базовой подготовки.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Terraria has got to be one of my favourite games in my lifeAlthough u may see that i havent played this as much coz i've always had Terraria cracked. It was only then Terraria was on Sale on steam so i decided to buy it to be kept up to the latest version automatically.Anywho, Terraria is a game where u go on adventures. Hunt, mine, dig, fish, craft, and build.Well, since a lot of people are comparing this to Minecraft, I'm gonna join in the fun!Some may say that Minecraft and Terraria are similar games but i can say that both are completely different. Having experienced both games, I noticed that Minecraft is much more creative in its mechanical aspect whereas Terraria is more RPG-like.CREATIVENESSITYMinecraft is 3D (Duh) and has a lot of different ways to build a house or an office tower by using all 3 dimensions to fit different designs for every wall.Terraria, being 2D, is limited in that structure as you're restricted to foreground and background only.FIGHTINGLYNESSITYMinecraft has limited combat as in its current state only has Swords and Bows. Although the tools can also be used as weapons but they are meant to be tools. The only way to expand this system is by installing mods unless Mojang adds more.Terraria consist of 3 different classes in its combat mechanics: Warrior, Ranger and Sorcerer. Warrior being the one with Melee weapons like Shortswords, Longswords, Polearms, Flails and Boomerangs also having the highest defense due to class-based armor. Ranger, one with the Bows, Repeaters and Guns has the highest DPS. Sorcerer is mainly the support class but its the longest lasting class as they have the ability to heal others or themselves if they are equipping the endgame armor.NOTE: In Minecraft, there's Enchanting to improve weapons and armor with higher values of damage and resistance respectively. In Terraria, you have prefixes that changes a weapon's stats negatively or positively.NON-PLAYABLE-CHARACTERSNESSITYMinecraft has villagers as NPCs. Consist of a Farmer, Blacksmith, Priest, Librarian and Butcher.Terraria has multiple NPCs and are unique in their own way. Consist of the Guide, Nurse, Merchant, Painter, Dye Trader, Demolitionist, Dryad, Arms Dealer, Party Girl, Stylist, Angler, Goblin Tinkerer, Witch Doctor, Clothier, Mechanic, Pirate, Truffle, Steampunker, and Cyborg.You are also able to get Santa himself as an NPC.Each and every one of these Terrarian NPCs has a randomly generated list of names.BOSSNESSITYMinecraft has the Ender Dragon and the Wither.Terraria has the Eye of Cthulhu, King Slime, Eater of Worlds, Brain of Cthulhu, Queen Bee, Skeletron, Wall of Flesh, The Twins, Destroyer, Skeletron Prime, Plantera, Golem and Duke Fishron. On the console and mobile version of Terraria, there's the Ocram and Lepus.There's more bosses for Terraria but they are Event based.BIOMENESSITYMinecraft has a very very long list of Biomes but they only vary in height and scale like Plains, Mountains, and Oceanic. To summarise the list of biomes: Grasslands, Forests, Jungles, Oceans, Deserts, Savanna, and Mesa. Including some weird looking biomes such as the Nether, Mushroom, and The End.Terraria seem to fall short on the variety of biomes as to summarise them: Forest, Desert, Jungle, Corruption, Crimson, Mushroom, Ocean, Hallow, and Space.That is about all for my Review although it's more of a comparison.I just want to say that Terraria seemed to be longer lasting due to its rich content without mods. However, Minecraft also has much to provide for but falls short when compared out of the creativity aspect.To conclude - Get Terraria if you're the type of person who loves APRGs that doesnt have regenerated maps.Get Minecraft if you love to travel far and wide to explore undiscovered structures such as the Ocean Monument and/or Desert Pyramids.I personally recommend Terraria to any sandbox / RPG lovers out there. Seriously, i've spent more than 2 years playing this game and i am not tired of it.My final verdict for Terraria is an 8/10

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
GeneralTerraria is a survival 2D RPG with free content updates, randomly generated worlds, and overall a masterpiece done right. Build, dig, chop, fight and survive are the 5 major elements in Terraria. Enemies that are small, to major bosses, you'll have your hands tied in an experience so great you don't want to stop playing.Terraria has proven to be one of the best 2D survival games for its multiplayer to play with friends, down to the part where it can be very hardcore to master. Terraria also has simple character creation, basically changing the color of your character's hair, body, etc.Building in Terraria is very basic and honestly great at times. Kill bosses to unlock npcs, build traps to protect your home from invasions or master it all with endgame gear. Yes, that's right: gear. Terraria has thousands of items to sell, keep or fight with. If you think you've done it all, re-think that.With a new team re-developing Terraria, they have made the expectations high for Terraria: reworking a lot of in-game features and adding brand new features like fishing or mounts to make you play even longer!My OpinionStill actively developed, Terraria is just one of those overwhelming games, if you've experienced it. Character creation is basic, which why would it be crazy? Half the armor you get in-game will basically cover your character up. Multiplayer is fun  when you play with friends, basically creating great structures, down to owning bosses. Terraria has been one of my favorite, well put together games ever since it released and when it was picked up to be continued via development.Thousands of items to collect, hundreds of bosses to kill, possibly thousands of enemies to conquer, and world changing difficult experiences.Terraria will keep you playing for a long time.OverallI have no complaints. Terraria is a great game overall.Rating: 10/10

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												TL; DR: I like this game a lot, but the Multiplayer on it, if you have no friends, is trash.Terraria is a game that, just like Minecraft, is about Survival and Building.The similarities stop there.While Minecraft is focused on Building (Being 3D), Terraria is mostly about the Survival and Discovery, which translates, in-game, to Explore, Get Materials and Progress.I recommend not using a Guide (Asides from the in-game "Guide" NPC), unless you really cannot advance. If you must, search "Terraria Wiki" on google, and read away.It has building as well, some more options than MC offers, including a wider selection of blocks and colors as well. Only things that ruin it, for me, are the lack of NPCs (For huge houses/cities) and the finite world (Get Starbound, if you want to build rather than survive, albeit they are adding hunger next update).The game is flawless, as long as you don't use the Cloud...--Not Affecting GAME Review--As for the community, it's trash, consisting of the Item Trinity, which are people who give items (Usually End-game, therefore ruining the Discovery aspect), which I call "Item Givers", a certain world containing every item in the game (Also destroying "Discovery"), which I call "Item Worlds" and those servers with the equivalent of MC's "/give" command, ruining the Discovery and Exploration aspects; I call those "Item Servers".Basically, if you want Discovery to be at it's max, avoid the "Item Trinity" (Item Giver, Item World and Item Server)....It's also overrun by kiddies who can't even type correctly, let alone play.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												This game, is incredible. I swear, look at my hours. 300+ hours of fun! I still haven't even beaten the game yet after 300 hours... mostly because it is a true challenge. I reccomend this game to hardcore gamers. If you aren't good with hard survival games that can be confusing at the beggining if no videos or people tell you anything about it. AND IT IS NOT ANYTHING LIKE MINECRAFT SO STOP SAYING THAT! Here are some tips throughout the game:First, get wood and make houses so that you and NPCs can live in them. For it to be a valid house, you need to have solid blocks, no  holes in the wall, a table and chair, and a background wall.Next, go mining and exploring. Don't forget to bring torches, NIGHT AND CAVES ARE REALLY DARK WITHOUT LIGHT.You may find cool gadgets that you can equip in your inventory, also, you should make some armor.Next, fight bosses such as the eye of cthulu and get even better gear.You can go and fight skeletron at the end of the world and have access into the dungeon.Keep playing the game and progressing further.Next, go to the bottom of the world, make a long, straight, pathway and then throw a guide voodoo doll into lava and fight the wall of flesh.You will now be in hardmode which makes a new biome and every enemy is buffed incredibley.I will let you continue from there on your own. Have fun :)

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												An overall interesting game, the idea of a 2D Minecraft confuses and interests me at the same time since I played the much hated Minecraft for many years before eventually switching over to Steam games in general. There really is not much to say about this game as it is really straight forward, but I'll give it a shot.I would like to start off by saying I have played a limited amount of time with this game and I have limited knowledge of it, so please understand this as you read my review. The first positive thing is the idea of the game. Someone has gone ahead and made a simpler version of MineCraft at a cheaper price (sort of). But honestly, that's also a negative, great idea, but you ripped it off someone...Now onto the actual game, it's frustrating that's for sure, in the 1 hour that I played it I made a good underground house (imo) and I was beginning to like it, then in about the period of 5 minutes I died maybe 5-6 times and my house became ridden with creatures. Certainly not the start I was looking for, but fun to deal with. In the next .7 hours it became apparent that I was a 'noob' the amount of crafting recipes and formulas was never ending, and I realised that this was not a simplified MineCraft, but rather a more advanced Minecraft...There, that's all I learnt from like 1.7 hours of it, do as you please, I sit on the fence.Overall Rating: 7/10

!! This review will be deleted after revision is made !!Terraria. A 2-Dimensional adventure in a pixelated reality. There isn't a specific objective for this game. (From my experience,) you're free to explore and do whatever you feel should be your goal.My opinions of it all:The GoodIt does have a few elements that remind me of Minecraft, but I wouldn't be one to say that majority of it is so. The soundtrack was nice, pleasant, relaxing. I found my expeditions to the unknown rather amazing; the randomly-generated worlds were astonishing to me upon first site. Those enemies, too. If only I could see more!The BadI don't know anything that I may need to speak of that I would consider bad about this game.OverallI haven't had a lot of experience in this game yet, but I did enjoy what I've been able to do before things happened. After I fix and survive my computer conflicts, I'll have this game another gander and edit this review for farther explanations. I wouldn't necessarily use this review to determine whether (you) want this game or not yet.--Sir Shinigami.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2013
Must buy at any price [✓]Worth the money but wait for a small sale [x]Wait for a huge discount [x]Avoid at all costs [x]Terraria, a game that offers tons of things to do, seriously look up how many items exist in this game...This game is reffered by many to "2D Minecraft" , don't let that fool you as this has ALOT more to offer...This game sadly isn't very story based but it's still an amazing experience especially with friends. The Beginning/Pre HardmodeIt starts of pretty slowly and like any survival game, get wood , build stuff to survive and get weapons/armor to survive. This however allows you to start off however you want, try speedrunning to a dungeon to get good items, or start of slowly and nicely and just collect wood and oresThen you'll start getting into the boss fight/even farming some, in Terraria you get a chance of getting 1 of these 2 worlds, the "Crimson" world and the "Corrpution" world. These are quite important but keep in mind they're biomes, they have different items/bosses in the 2 biomes, both are very unique aswell, theres 4 bosses in the beginning of the new world, the Corruption and Crimson biomes both have different bosses but it doesn't change the number of how many you can beat.You'll get to the "Devil of the world" which is called "WoF , Wall Of Flesh" and is the hardest "Pre Hardmode" boss you can get and definately the final one for this mode... Hardmode / End Game After you beat the Wall of Flesh you'll free "The Spirits of the World" and then your Crimson/Corruption will slowly spread across your world, theres going to be a new biome! More enemies / items, MORE BOSSES! And more challenges ahead of you, the game basically does this"Hey player! You just killed the Wall of Flesh! Have this awesome item!"Player:"Thanks! This is easy now!"Terraria"EASY?! Well you're doomed now!"You get 7 more bosses now! Double (Possibly TRIPLE) the items/enemies unlocked and you'll die alot at first, you'll then get Invasion events! You'll get invaded for a whole day in Terraria (Or less if you're OP) and keep dying, those are exciting though as you get items and a non stop fight experience, after you kill all the bosses many players consider it finished but there's more... Expert Mode / Character Levels Expert mode! Basically you start off with Hardmode and then get Expert mode which is double to triple as difficult as Hardmode...so have fun at looking at the "You have died" screen, there's a plus though!Limited to Expert only Items1 "End game boss" <-- considered to manyAnd overall a bigger challengeCharacter levels are something that you get when creating your character and theresSoftcore Mode - On death lose coinsMediumcore Mode - On death lose itemsHardcore Mode - On death you die permanently, gg rip character Servers / Item Servers Servers to play with friends! Easy to set up with Steam and overall good quality for how simple it is (You do get lag spikes if you're on a friends server unless its a LAN) and there's public servers that are amazing! There's actually custom gamemodes made by the community (1 or 2 were staged for multiplayers by devs!)Gamemodes found on servers (Keep in mind not all are listed these are examples)Capture the  DiamondPortal Gun MapsTeam DeathmatchBoss Battle Arenaand alot more!Item servers are a sort of problem of people spawning in items into chests and anyone can take them! Even the Expert mode items which sort of ruins the players/feelings of beating the boss legit but knowing people get those items for free by going on a item server...Keep in mind you don't get somehow banned/ your character deleted if you go on an item server, I haven't heard officialy if servers get put down if they give out free god mode items but I did see some get shut down (Unknown reasons) Mods and Modded Maps You get mods for items and modded maps for challenges / gamemodes (Portal maps /Team Deathmatch maps etc.) Thank you for reading this :) Like I said already this is my longest review / the review I put most time in and I'd like to thank you for reading all of this :)

content:
Posted: October 8, 2013
												Oh, My Good Friend Terraria...What Can I Say About It? It's Highly Regarded By Me And Many Friends Of Mine. We Play Terraria Constantly. And In Short, We Favor It HIGHLY Over Minecraft. Reasons Are That You Have More Ways To Fight, More Weapons, More Gore (Hellz Yea!), And More Everything Than Minecraft EVER Would Have. Plus, MInecraft Updates Are Tiny And Don't Give♥♥♥♥♥♥ Terraria Updates, While They Takes SOO Much Longer To Come Out, Produce MASSIVE Amounts Of Things That Make The Game SOO Much Better. In Minecraft, It's Diamond Set And You're God, Simple As That. In Terraria, It's So Much More Than That. You Don't Just Become God In Terraria, You Fight For Your Immortality. You Gain And You Seek Out The Loot That Rarely Rarely Drops. You Seek Out More Than Just Diamond Godmode, You Seek Out The Thrill Of Constant Battle, And Risk Yourself, But The Risk Just Adds To The Thrill. Even The Strongest Armor In The Game Doesn't Make You A God, It Just Makes You Harder To Kill. Diamond Armor In Minecraft Is Just A Stupid Godmode For Cowardly Players Who Don't Give Two ♥♥♥♥s About Risk. Plus, Minecraft Is So Much More Costly, For Features That We Don't Really Give Two ♥♥♥♥s About. So In Short, Terraria Outmatches Minecraft In Ways So Numerous, And So Amazing, Nothing Beats Them. Plus, Minecraft's Combat Is Just Poke Poke Poke Poke Ded. Terraria's Combat Is Shooting, Slicing n Dicing, And Spellcasting. Suck On That, Minecraft!

												When I first bought this game I wanted an old style scroller, with a Minecraft feel. Knowing that there are a lot of games similar to Minecraft, I had a lot of games to look at. One game that kept on coming up was Terraria. I knew my friends had played it, but I didn't know much about it. I decided, "Heck, I'll give it a shot." Little did I know...Wow, this game is hard. Let me rephrase that. It is more difficult than I thought. When the night comes, you better have a shelter, or else the monsters are gonna mess you up. It also has a lot of stuff to do. Build, craft, fight, mine, multiplayer... I'm still getting into it, but so far, I like what I see.

												Addictive little surprise of a game.  Reminds me of an ancient video game I played as a kid called Below the Root, but with zombies.   Generates a entirely random pixelated little world to explore populated with creatures, monsters, treasure and adventure.   Build shelter from the zombies at night, mine, craft weapons and explore above and below ground.  Don't like the world?  Just destroy it and create a new one to live in.  Really Cool!

content:
Posted: August 30, 2013
												Terraria brings you a very impressive 2D adventure game. Its simple gameplay design, brightly coloured world and the ability to shape an entire village with actual NPCs make it a decent game. What makes it a great game however, is the enormously expansive amount of things there are to be found in Terraria. The lots of bosses, special events every few in-game days and an absolute boatload of items increased Terraria's play-a-bility enormously for me; even after more than 35 hours, I feel that I haven't even seen 10% of the entire game. Lastly, the cooperative system in Terraria is very decently executed, although server issues will sometimes ensue. Definitely a must-buy if you're a fan of Minecraft!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												This game is great, and let me explain my reasons why:So this game, to some is a minecraft clone, and there is only a few things the same about them- sandbox, pixel graphics and no set goal besides general advancement (nothing wrong with that)How is that meant to be a clone? You cannot claim inspiration as copying, especially when there is so little the same.it is a game that requires some patience, but a variety of enemies, weapons and armourm all better than the last and some even with special unique properties can make it worth it.The building is simple, and npc's are fairly easy to aquire, with some tasks that have to be met so that they don't all just jump in your house.The biomes are all unique, and the day night cycle drives a nice contrast between frolicking in a field and slaughtering zombies and giant eyes.If you look at the negative reviews, quite a few seem to say 'reached the end game and got bored' and yet most of those people haven't even played for 10 hours, let allone used a variety of ranged, melee and magic.Speaking of it, the 3 damage types allow for your own style, a tanky melee fighter that gets up close to enemies, an extremely damaging ranger, who is balanced out by lower defense and a need to buy ammo, or a squishy mage that deals huge bursts of damage before waiting for mana.There are over 10 tiers of gear, the first view being a bit boring I will admit, but once you kill the deadly Wall of Flesh, you get into hardmode, and THIS is where it gets really fun.The enemies are more unique and harder, there are souped up versions of previous bosses, with their own new wys to murder you face, and the gear gets much better.There are also 2 variants to most gear, and which you will get changes in each world.Now I played at least 500 hours in singleplayer, and even minecraft, which was my main game for ~3 years hasn't racked up that kind. Then one day it was on sale, and my friends got it. I now have 700+ hours!Multiplayer is easy and quick, though you must be careful of people with twinked items (or a friend that has an obsession with dynamite...) ANYWAY This game is amazing, and I haven't even covered all the good areas!The building is nice, with MANY blocks and background walls to use, and if you do it right you can make it so monsters don't spawn in your fancy new wooden house.More good things I am too lazy to type!This game may not be your cup of tea, mostly if you are not one for these sandbox games without much of a storyline, but if you are I strongly reccommend it!9/10, only reason it is not 10/10 is because NOTHING is perfect.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
												Many people call Terraria '2D Minecraft'. While that is true in the sense that it has mining, construction, and sandbox aspects, Terraria is so much more. Hundreds of items, swarms of unique enemies, and 'easy to play hard to master' gameplay makes for a very well rounded experience. Don't let the pixelated graphics or the side-scrolling aspect turn you away. The dynamic lighting is very nice. Carrying a torch will light up the area around you. You can throw glow sticks down into caves to see what's ahead. You can even buy a mining helmet, and won't have to worry about carrying a light with you at all! One of the things I found impressive was the way liquids work. Water settles. Lava flows the way one would imagine lava should flow. Want to flood an entire cave? Dig a tunnel from the ocean and let it flow. All in all, Terraria is a spectacular game. It has multiplayer support, and the combat system ties in well with that. The most recent update (1.2) has effectively /doubled/ the saize of an already impressive game. Would recommend to anyone.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												Generally I'm not the biggest sandbox fan, but this game has done it better than any other game I've played.They've somehow made a small limited world feel as vast as an open world Bethesda game, and that's what has made this game something to behold. It has a fast paced real time RPG feel that many players can get into, but the normal sandbox elements that fans of other sandbox games can enjoy just as much. Everything is just wonderful in this game: the soundtrack, the bosses, the building, just about everything builds onto each other in order to create something special. You could even grab a buddy or two, or even 5 or 10, and just have a blast playing the game together, exploring your completely new world.Terraria is a little bit of something for everyone, and I believe that it deserves a well earned spot on everyone's library.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Terraria is a 2D Minecraft. That right there is an uneducated and ignorant summary of the indie masterpiece which is Terraria. While some of the concepts are alike Minecraft, it is unique in it's RPG elements and wide variety of items which is well over that of Minecraft's amount. With over 1000 different items and blocks, just under 20 NPCs, 100s of enemies and a charming retro artstyle, there is little I can find that disappoints me in this game. Gameplay is relatively simple and even though once you get up to the Frost Moon event you will still find new things to do. On top of that the game is actively being updated; with updates providing players with a hefty amount of new content. Multiplayer is good fun although I prefer the more easygoing experience of singleplayer. Like most games there are large public servers but you can easily make LAN and Private servers with the aid of programs such as LogMeIn Hamachi. Terraria is a relaxing, fun and unique sandbox; don't listen to the naysayers who shun this game because of it's small and irrelevant similarities to Minecraft.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I have stopped playing this game.That doesn't mean it is bad; it is an exceedingly excellent game. I simply stopped playing because I wanted to be able to play other games as well. But I have nominated this for the Test of Time award on Steam because I believe this is one game I will always fondly look back on and will definitely replay in the future, if only for its free content updates (which you rarely find in the gaming world nowadays!)Its art style may look dated, but the level of polish totally points to a development team that cares so much about this game. It has some great ambient music as well.However, that is not where Terraria's strength as a game lies. It is in its escalating difficulty, in the expansive discovery and combat gaming experience it gives you as a player who explores a sandbox world. I highly recommend this to players who are into action games, and to a lesser extent creative players who want to design marvelous structures within the confines of a 2D game.Also, this game is just so much fun with friends!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												I r8 8/8 m8It's a great indie game, and the recent updates have only made it better. Honestly, all I could ask for now is larger world sizes... because why not?Gameplay is smooth, doesn't take a beastly PC to run Terraria. The music is beautiful and the graphics are a one-way ticket for the nostalgia train.The player isn't restricted by anything, you don't have to do things in a certain way. While there are class specializations in terms of armor or weapons, that doesn't mean you can't do whatever you want, whenever you want. Building is fun, and less tedious than it is in Minecraft (another great title). There are endless block choices, and there is a multitude of furniture to suit your needs. I don't know what you want, man, but if it's a side-scrolling survival crafting game, then this is the right place to look.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Terraria is a 2D Minecraft. That right there is an uneducated and ignorant summary of the indie masterpiece which is Terraria. While some of the concepts are alike Minecraft, it is unique in it's RPG elements and wide variety of items which is well over that of Minecraft's amount. With over 1000 different items and blocks, just under 20 NPCs, 100s of enemies and a charming retro artstyle, there is little I can find that disappoints me in this game. Gameplay is relatively simple and even though once you get up to the Frost Moon event you will still find new things to do. On top of that the game is actively being updated; with updates providing players with a hefty amount of new content. Multiplayer is good fun although I prefer the more easygoing experience of singleplayer. Like most games there are large public servers but you can easily make LAN and Private servers with the aid of programs such as LogMeIn Hamachi. Terraria is a relaxing, fun and unique sandbox; don't listen to the naysayers who shun this game because of it's small and irrelevant similarities to Minecraft.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												A very simple seeming game, however its actual complexity suprised me, and positively so. THis is what many would call a side scroller, however even within the 2D world, there are many things to suprise you, to excite you, and to amuse you. Minecraft players can understand some of what is going on, though expect to have to figure stuff out along the way, or get help, as you go. If you do not like 4E style games, then you may not enjoy this. I would recommend Terraria to all others though, wait for a sale sure. But you are missing out on a game that can be enjoyed almost forever. Randomly generated worlds, with characters that can cross between them, have a storage world, and mine in others!!

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												If you start playing Terraria is really confusing in the first place. The crafting system is a bit strange since everything is really small and you need a lot of different workplaces to craft different stuff. Secondly you dont really know what to do, so you start digging and build a house, maybe you find the first NPC. Then you craft your first stuff and kill some enemies ... still it doesnt make any sence.But then, suddenly there is an event or the first random boss spawn and you cry like a baby, running from the boss or the mobs. Now you now, i have to get better equipment and you start discovering the caves and somehow find some chests with nice items and now you feel ready to kill everything. You encounter the boss you lost before and kill him, thats fantastic!!!!But, oh no, whats that? There is another boss and youre where you startet the boss before. After a while you understand how to craft, you get good equip and youre ready to face the monsters in the underworld. After beating the wall of flesh you feel like a campion, but then you realize ... that was just the beginning!!!!Beside this unbelieveable good 2D action, there are so much cute and funny things that make you laught all the time you play. The cute and lovingly created skins for your character and the sheer endless opportunities to style your houses and rooms, the NPCs and all the different enemys.All this makes Terraria a ♥♥♥♥ing great game and i enjoyed playing it a lot!10/10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Incredible game, which has a thing for everyone. You can do anything you want - explore the mysterious underground caves, search for hidden loot, build pretty structures and pixel art, hunt down rare monsters, try to get your hands on rare weapons and artefacts, defend your home from invading enemies, make a town with tons of villagers to attract, fight tons of diverse bosses with unique loot and abilities, enjoy yourself fishing for random rewards, etc.  For just 5$, the game is really overkill - i'd give it 10-15$ tbh, just for the giant progress that it made since the initial release. Also note, that the awesome updates Cenx, Crowno, Yoraiz0r and others give us are completely free! And they are surely gonna support the game even after Terraria: Otherworld will be out.  If you really wanted a game where you could build, find rare stuff and murder giant bosses, then this game is for you!10/10 ~Crixalis

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												I have put many hours into this game (400+). It is a 2D roleplaying sandbox with decent replay value however multiplayer is most likely the strongest part of the game. You can team up with your friends and play throught he game like you would in single player except with friends. On certain servers you can build with friends or strangers or pvp others for glory.While the begining stages of the game can get dull it picks up the pace once you defeat your first boss or two.The game is built upon 3 main classes Melee Ranger and Mage although there is no skill tree and you don't pick your class until later on in the game when you start getting more advanced armors with buffs for certain weapon types etc. This is where the replay value comes in. Many people call this a "2D minecraft" however it is so much more with both games having there own ups and downs.My final verdict is that if you are a fan of 2D games, RPG's or Sandboxes you should probobaly pick this game up if not then it isn't for you.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Dear Gamers,if you love Pixels and 2D platform games,I highly recommend you that game.Terraria is one of my favourite game I've spent so much time on.I almost only play games on Steam that owe cards and achievements,but here it was totally different.I had really much funs to play it and I do not regret all the hours spent on it.It has so much stuffs to do that you can't be annoyed by the game.Maybe the beginning, because it has a slow beginning but oh well!It's like that in 90 % games. And this one is really complete.Even before them last update, they made it so you can do what ever you want.Either you can have fun to do beautiful and giant buildings,either you can chase all the bosses and farm some to get strong items,awesome/fun accessories (Like, allowing you to fly.. Double jump.. ect..!)Instead of Minecraft, this one do really owe an objective.You will have to grow a town (not obviously a town, but it is really advised to regroup all your NPCat one place instead of spreading them all in the map) where you can regroup many NPC's.Most of them will require a condition.One would ask you to owe a gun, another one would ask you to save them (tied up in a castle, chased off of them tribe..)and you would have to conditions about the house. (Usually, one table, 2 chairs and a room big enough. Wall taken care of, and roof closed. With at least one door and one chest.)Over time, you become a badass. Your armor can make you run very fast, make light, make counter-damage.. Many kind of things.If you like crazy games where everything is allowed, oh please, get yourself Terraria and enjoy the crazy fun you can get off of it.Also, it's very cheap. (Especially in Steam Sold)I guess I am done, since it's been kind of a while I didn't played it I can't remember of every details,but I do believe and I do hope that you are going to have fun with that game. See you! :)

content:
Posted: June 20, 2012
												This game is one of the most juicy games I have ever played. It's so good I don't even know what to say about it.The amount of things to do in this game is just overflowing out the buttocks. You explore the vast terrain in search of fertile land where you will set up your base. Then you begin creating tools to help you dig into the earth and find delicious minerals and creating weapons to fend off the creatures that seek to body you.Then you can expand your base to make room for storage, crafting areas, and PVP arenas. You can continue your underground search and find treasures and juicy dog treats. And then you can begin taking down bosses and exploring the more dangerous areas of the corruption, the jungle, and the dungeon. At a certain point, you unlock hard mode and the slams and jams continue from there.With that said, this game will keep you occupied for quite some time. And the fun you will experience multiplies if you are playing with friends. Don't think about whether this game is worth your money or not, just take out your wallet and do it fat kid. I ain't spreadin' lies here.I give Terraria a score of "10/10 chewy like an eggroll". Thank you for reading.

												Terraria is a very excellent game filled with hours of gameplay. Including things like exploring, fighting, building, crafting, etcYou create a customized character and can rearrange much of the land to your liking to build all sorts of buildings and areas. You craft items and blocks from other items picked up. Quite a bit of fun random events. Once you get to a certain point, you can unlock Hardmode which opens up a huge amount of additional block, items, NPCs, monsters, events into the game.It's an excellent game and has so many interesting equipment to use and mess around with. For example, a useful tool to explore and climb things are different types of Grappling Hooks. Be sure to check out not just land and underground, but also the skies. There are some interesting Clouds with treasures. However, be sure to be equipped well, the monsters are much tougher up there. The game itself is worth the cost and in my opinion is very awesome.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												I have put many hours into this game (400+). It is a 2D roleplaying sandbox with decent replay value however multiplayer is most likely the strongest part of the game. You can team up with your friends and play throught he game like you would in single player except with friends. On certain servers you can build with friends or strangers or pvp others for glory.While the begining stages of the game can get dull it picks up the pace once you defeat your first boss or two.The game is built upon 3 main classes Melee Ranger and Mage although there is no skill tree and you don't pick your class until later on in the game when you start getting more advanced armors with buffs for certain weapon types etc. This is where the replay value comes in. Many people call this a "2D minecraft" however it is so much more with both games having there own ups and downs.My final verdict is that if you are a fan of 2D games, RPG's or Sandboxes you should probobaly pick this game up if not then it isn't for you.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Incredible game, which has a thing for everyone. You can do anything you want - explore the mysterious underground caves, search for hidden loot, build pretty structures and pixel art, hunt down rare monsters, try to get your hands on rare weapons and artefacts, defend your home from invading enemies, make a town with tons of villagers to attract, fight tons of diverse bosses with unique loot and abilities, enjoy yourself fishing for random rewards, etc.  For just 5$, the game is really overkill - i'd give it 10-15$ tbh, just for the giant progress that it made since the initial release. Also note, that the awesome updates Cenx, Crowno, Yoraiz0r and others give us are completely free! And they are surely gonna support the game even after Terraria: Otherworld will be out.  If you really wanted a game where you could build, find rare stuff and murder giant bosses, then this game is for you!10/10 ~Crixalis

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Wow!I have had this game in my Steam Library for nearly two years and had only played it once , for about 10 minutes before uninstalling it. I didn't understand how it worked. Plain and simple. Frankly I was spoiled by the flagrantly straightforward nature of Minecraft.  Here recently though, and for no reason whatsoever, other than; I guess, curiosity, and the fact that I’m burned smooth the heck out on Minecraft, I decided to give it another shot.First, let me say this: I love Minecraft, but seriously, aside from building some random things, some quite cool, and proclaiming, "Look what I made," there isn’t much to it. You can pretty much see everything there is to see, in a mere five hours of goofing around, if not much less. Terraria, on the other hand, is massive! I am constantly surprised by just how enormous this game is. I’m actually quite stupefied by this games lack of visibility. After spending some time with it, I can’t see why anyone would even want to play Minecraft. This game has everything and way, way more. Its just 2D, which is probably a turn off to most and pixel art, BUT, it’s fluidly animated, with tight, precise controls and runs fantastically on even the most basic system. The particle effects and simple physics, along with plenty of gratifying explosions, colorful dismemberment, -of enemies….and you- are pleasing enough to allow most people, I would imagine, to get passed their initial deterrents with relative ease. What really grabbed me about this game, wasn't just the overall vastness of the map, but the incredible range of craftable items, armor and weapons. It feels so nice when you get a rare drop or find a new more powerful weapon or accessory, that makes traversing the world easier. It starts out rough and certainly seems mind numbingly basic, but get past that, and you will find that it’s well worth the time. Just dig deeper, literally, the games best content, by far, is deep below the surface of the world.Me, I love to explore and find new things. I love getting more powerful weapons and not having to worry about breaking or losing them, due to some stupid, unavoidable event (although there are harder modes which penalize you a bit more ruthlessly; dropping gear, items and even permanent character loss for the Hardcore players). I love going back to places I used to get trounced in and do the trouncing. If I can bring a friend to help, all the better. The co-op in Terraria is crazy fun. My girlfriend and I, are enthralled. I Highly recommend this game to couples who, along with knowing how to portforward and research how to run their own servers (it’s easy) also love exploration and loot quest games. For instance: Do you love Zelda games? Metroid Games? Castlevania, maybe? This is your game and For 10 bucks, you are basically stealing it. Note: If you get confused on how to start, or what to do in general. If the size of the game overwhelms you, don't worry, there are plenty of immensely entertaining YouTube videos of people playing from start to finish as well superfluous wiki.Have fun.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												A lot of people say that Terraria is just 2D Minecraft. And on the surface, the two are very similar. But dig deeper (pun intended), and the differences start to emerge. I have put quite a few hours into Terraria, and I quite enjoyed it. Its combination of sandbox creativity, RPG-like dungeon crawling, and seemingly endless stream of items and bosses kept the game interesting. There are a few problems that I had with it, but most of them could be solved with mods or a few minor updates. Overall, I had a very good time with Terraria, and I most certainly would recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the survival, sandbox, or RPG genres.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Terraria is a game about fighting evil that is taking over the world, more or less. The game has a lot in place for a lot of different people. Obviously some people prefer to fight enemies 24/7 and others prefer to build a deluxe house with the finest of furniture. I'm both of those.Terraria is probably famous because of its "bosses," probably the most known one the Eye of Cthulhu. I think some people get a bad idea about the game from this "boss" aspect. If you REALLY don't want to fight bosses, (which I don't exactly recommend) you can choose to avoid them and just not continue in the game.The game is filled with so much content it's unbelievable. You think of something that would help you in the game, chances are it's been added! I used to play mostly in the time of 1.2 but I recently started playing again for 1.3.1, and there are a LOT of new features.To sum my longest review up, Terraria is right for you no matter what you want. "There's something for everyone," as the wiki describes it.TL;DR: You'll like it either way. Buy it.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Terraria is a Teen rated sandbox sidescroller where you create a charecter, fight monsters, search for supplies, build communities and of course hang with friends. Now when I first played this, I wasen't a noob. (I played it on Xbox)  I knew instantly how to play. Enough bragging about my winnings. It's time to give you what you wan't. This game is well known for it's bosses & minions. It's also known for it's badass level customization. Like...uh. You want to dress up like that alien from Aliens? Well now you can get it & wear it ingame. Some bosses include skeletron, the eater of worlds, eye of cthulhu and the very own twins. Most of these bosses require you to think of a way to trap them, attack them or block them. And now you say...What else is here? I like what I hear.Well timmy, I shall say that last up is the biomes or places.Inside this game there a lots of places for you to visit..such as: Space, Hell, Underground (cave), underwater, juungle, desert and the winter forest. Now this game arouses you, you say? Well. GO BUY IT THEN!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												One of the best games on Steam that everyone needs to buy. It is one giant sandbox and you can explore wherever you want. Dig to the bottom of the world, or fly all the way up to space. Building up your character from your basic clothes and pickaxe, into some of the games best equipment feels very rewarding. Lots of random events keep things fresh. You never know what will happen in each game world day (or night). Building a base of operations is another highlight. There are hundreds of different items you can use to build a house, or whatever you want, to store all your treasures you have found throughout the game. You also need to build a place for all the NPCs to stay. They offer lots of different items you can buy from them, so its important that you don't drop them off into a lava pit somewhere (besides the Guide).There are over 10 bosses in the game and they all provide a great challenge that you need to be well prepared for. They also drop some of the game's best loot and defeating them is a requirement in order to progress through the game. There are so many different equipment combinations you can use in the game, that everyone has a different strategy for each boss. Fight them however you want. Build a giant arena for an epic fight, create a complex trap system to kill the boss in, or shoot them from long range with your laser pistol. Anything is possible.Each time you create a world, it is randomly generated. This means no 2 worlds will have anything in the same places. There are also lots of mods for the game for when you want to try something different. Some overhaul the game drastically and are very worth checking out.The game can easily last you hundreds of hours. Especially if you are playing with friends.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Simply one of the best indie games I have ever, or probably will ever own. The first thing pretty much everything thinks upon first seeing this game is that it's just a 2D minecraft. That couldn't be farther from the truth. While it may share some similarties with Minecraft, it's so much different than it in so many ways. Most of them make this game far superior to Minecraft as well.Pros:Fun Combat (bosses, special enemies, really really awesome weapons)Huge amount of different materials to build withHundreds of weapons and armor to craftSoundtrackTons of NPC's that spawn in the world to sell you stuff and guide your wayTons of biomes and caves to exploreReplayabilityCons:Most people would say the fact that Terraria is 2D is a con. While that may be somewhat true as far as building goes, the combat works brilliantly in 2D. It's far more fun than anything you will find in any other sandbox game.I love this game to death. You won't find a better sandbox game out there. It only took me a mere 10 minutes of killing slimes and running around so find out that I had gotten my money's worth. Just buy this game. You won't regret it.

There's also an Expert mode, which lives up to it's name and gives even seasoned veterans some major difficulties, as one mistake can lead to instant death. The amount of weapons/blocks/accessories/monsters/bosses etc. is astounding.10/10

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												To anyone who is considering buying this game, buy it, you won't regret it at all.this is the first game I bought on steam and I've now got a wide variety of games but I always go back to terraria, this is a classic game which you have to give a go. Starting out with just a copper shortsword, picaxe and axe you set out on your jourrney to explore your own, randomly generated 2d world.Terraria has low computer requirements to play the game so even if you have a poor computer you can still enjoy this amazing game. Terraria is all about exploring and progressing in your world while developing your city to have room for all the npc's.Starting off at the beginning the game seems a little unbalanced but you will quickly improve your weapons and materials to tilt the game in your favour. Even once you have done this though you should be up to hardcore mode bringing the difficulty right back. I have played terraria for about 550 hours and I still enjoy sitting down and playing it for a few hours. No matter how many times you complete the game you can still go back and play it through again. I haven't mentioned something yet which defiently needs a mention. Multiplayer.Multiplayer is a key feature of this game and is in my opinion as good as singleplayer, probably even better. When you find a server which you like, it is a real community feeling. You get to know the players and you can enjoy pvp, building, survival and exploration. This game has given me many hours of enjoyment and hopefully this review has helped you to decide to buy terraria because I cannot recommened this game enough.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Terraria could be described as a 2D-Minecraft, but this wouldn't do the game justice. Terraria is a fun and charming sandbox game, with light RPG mechanics. The richer enemy variety and the several bosses, combined with the light-RPG progression  add a feeling of purpose that might appeal to those who see no point in playing games like Minecraft. On the construction front it isn't as enjoyable as Minecraft, because the 2D-environment limits your creativity to an extent. But this is not to say that you can't have fun with just building in the game. But it won't go as far as it does in Minecraft since the game does have a focus on exploration, adventures and combat which serves it well but is also a double-edged sword.Terraria is well worth your money, especially if you grab it on sale. The game can at the very least offer you tens of hours of fun and enjoyable gameplay.

Posted: February 18, 2014
												First of all you can't compare it in any way with Minecraft. Those 2 games are completely different from each other because Terraria is more focused on dungeons/PvE/PvP while Minecraft is more focused on the building part. Of course you do a lot of PvP and PvE in MC as well but in Terraria it's an essential part of the game.I really enjoyed playing this game especially with friends. It's really funny to mine around with friends, farm things to kill your first boss, to loot the dungeons and so on!The only thing I have to say is that once you did everything in the game it gets reaally boring. Ofc they try to update the game as much as possible but often times it's mainly a little patch bringing up a few more items.This game is a must-buy game when it's on sale if not a must-have game overall!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												So, having been a longtime minecraft fan and avid player, i made the bad decision to transfer to windows 8.1, which ruined my ability to play my beloved pickaxe simulator because of the compatibility issues with my driver. so, i decided to browse steam for an alternative. and then i stumbled across this little gem, Terraria. at first sight, the visuals are pixelated, retro, and enjoyable. character creation is fairly deep for something animated in pixels, and it is essentially a 2D version of minecraft with alot more customisation in terms of the things you can make, the items you can gain, and the armours, clothes, furniture... etc.  beneath that, there is a host of NPC's that come along every now and then that just make the game even better; combined with the bosses, and the sheer sizes and depths (and heights) of the randomly generated worlds, and then the damnable hardmode that you can access which adds a hell of alot of epic things (crafting wings, super equipment and revamped super bosses) it astounds me that I hadn't picked up this game before. in short: great game, good visuals, with addictive gameplay that keeps this indie title at the top of my list.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
GREAT SHOW<GOOD SHOWBAD SHOWAWFUL SHOW2D Minecraft, but not really. The only bad thing about this game is that it has the same symptoms of every survival games now, which is the WIKI/GUIDE symptom. You have to look up on the internet what you have to do next in the game in order to proceed.It has more bosses, more stuff to do in-game, overall more content.The combat is simple, but is still great, especially since there are tons of weapons with different effects in the game.I mentioned bosses, and there are tons of them, and they are not easy to beat. But that's what most gamers want these days right? A challenge?The level, and items are randomly generated, so it is always a different experience when you start over.You always get different loot, and there are tons of loot in the game.The music, is okay, suitable, and changes depending on where you are and what you're doing, but needs more variants. Nonetheless good.Overall it's great. I'm not sure if 100 hours is enough to prove that I have the rights to say that or not. Hopefully so.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												I've never been in an abusive relationship before.  As a strong, empowered woman, I'm proud to say that about myself.  I have self-respect.  I have independence.  I know how to establish emotional walls and judge when someone is being cruel to me.No, Terraria isn't mean to me.  Terraria just tries to teach me lessons.  It punishes me when I'm stupid - I deserve it.  Terraria warned me not to go obsidian farming in a cramped tunnel after three hours of ore collecting and spelunking.  It said "baby, don't do that, you're going to die from lava somehow."  And I said, whatever, I got this!  I'm on a roll!And then the lava came through the water above me somehow, and I died.  And all of my equipment was lost.This was before I realized your equipment is only recoverable if you DON'T log out immediately in a rage after dying.  You have to suck it up and get back down there.I can't count the number of times I've run furious into dark tunnels because my lazy♥♥♥♥♥didn't put torches up, fumbling around looking deep in the bowels of the earth with a recall potion half-corked and ready.  But I get my gear back, every time after that.And every time I get uppity, Terraria is there to hit me (gently, in the face, multiple times, until I cry) and remind me what a stupid ♥♥♥♥♥ I am, and how I just need to learn my place and stop trying to go underground so much.Terraria loves me.  It gave me fairy wings and powered armor, and a shark machine gun that shoots homing green bullets.  I love Terraria, too.  You just don't understand Terraria like I do.  What we have is different.Terraria can show me such tenderness, except when it's eclipsing and shoving hordes of swamp monsters and vampires down my throat, even though I'm begging it to stop because I'm running out of ammo, because I thought a pile of 2,000 would be enough.Terraria always finds ways to ♥♥♥♥ me over and make me say "thank you, baby."  Oh god.  I need to get away from this game.
