content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												Ah, Terraria versus Minecraft, the classic debate. Or at least has been since around 2012, so maybe not all that classic.Before I played this game, I held this belief that it was a 2D ripoff of Minecraft. And that may be true, but in this case the ripoff is far better then the original.So, to start, I created a new character - he could be either softcore, mediumcore, or hardcore, but not that kind, get your mind out of the gutter. Softcore characters drop money on death, mediumcore loses items, and hardcore characters die forever.Next came the new world. I joined in 1.2, so I didn't have a chance to try Expert Mode, the super-hard version with more rewarding rewards, at least until now in 1.3. The loading screen was full of phrases like "making dirt" "placing rocks in the dirt" "placing dirt in the rocks" and so on. One message, though, read "making the world evil", which made me panic until it hit me that it was probably a joke. How wrong I was.That message was a reference to the game's unique biomes; your world can end up with a section of Corruption (dark and evil-looking) or Crimson (highly visceral), but never both.You spawn with some basic copper tools and an NPC called the Guide who gives very obvious "tips", but he can also tell you what anything you have in your inventory is used for.After much metroidvania-ing, I stumbled across the Corruption: "Oh, so this is what 'making the world evil' means." At this point you need to explore it so that you can make an eyeball used for summoning a bigger eyeball (that flies and has teeth) to kill. Then you get the game's most useless NPC, the Dryad, who literaly sells a glorified shovel ("The Dirt Rod allows the magical power of moving dirt!"). She becomes more useful later on, however, so don't let the zombies kill her (oh yes, I forgot about the zombies!).The next boss you should fight is the Eater of Worlds, a giant worm that lives in the Corruption. Or the Brain of Cthulhu if you end up with Crimson. Though I recommend you explore the Jungle a bit to get some half-decent weapons and armour, or a meteor crater if one lands.It's more fun to discover most of the content for yourself, however! So I'll leave you guessing about quite a lot.After digging down for a while, you'll get to Hell, and you can make some gear out of Hellstone, and the gear will look like it's made of lava. Yes, lava. Rule of Cool, everybody!Kill some demons and one will drop a voodoo doll of the guide. You then drop this into lava and kill the guide. You then run away from a terrifying "Wall of Flesh" that will try to kill you.After defeating the Wall, the Corruption/Crimson (Remember those!?) will start spreading through your world. You also get a second, "good" (or is it?) spreading biome called the Hallow, which has blue grass and lots of unicorns. This is when the Dryad becomes useful; she can help you stop these biomes spreading and taking over, but she wants you to root for the Hallow (if Hallow is actually evil, is the Dryad evil?).Now, this section of the game is called Hardmode, and my recommendation is to smash any plant bulbs you find in the Underground Jungle. No, go on, it won't summon a giant venus flytrap that wants to eat you or anything. And the evil plant will absolutely not drop a key to a Mayan temple full of lizards where you can fight a giant golem, most likely setting off an alien invasion. That will never happen.So to conclude, Terraria is a lot more than just "2D Minecraft". There's far more NPCs than the ones I just mentioned, too.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												-Terraria-So, uh, another serious review. Yippee.Gameplay:Ummm. It's barely similar to Minecraft, but it's the only way I can think of to start this off. So, when you start up the game, you get some character creation. Cool. NEXT. After that, you're going to start off. IT's the usual, get wood, build crafting table, get better tools, etc. Cool. But after that, nothing's similar to Minecraft. Terraria focuses more on exploration/combat, and even includes things such as boss battles, and when you beat the "final boss", a harder difficulty. Then endgame comes and there's nothing to do. Yay. But overall, it kept me for about 100 hours. Then Starbound came. (Review for Starbound comes later.) And at endgame, well, all you can do is build. And build. And build. Yeah. That last part took off a point.Story:...Uhh. There's not really a story or lore to this game as far as I know...yeah. Nothing here.Extra: The music's alright, controls are tight, movement's fun.Overall, 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												I was originally going to give this a negative review because I liked the console version better, I decided to give this game another spin the other day, and I love it. If you played the console version, this isn't much different. The game, being known for being a "clone" by Minecraft fanboys, is much different from Minecraft. This game is focused on combat and boss battles, unlike MInecraft, which is for sandbox creation, not combat, even with mods. I find the gameplay to be intense and enjoyable, especially with boss battles. I remember my friend and I always becoming overconfident and thinking we can beat Skeletron, even with our strategies all planned out, but we got whooped all the time. It was funny, enjoyable, and addicting. I wanted to relive these days, so I got the PC version. I did find the crafting menu a bit harder to understand because for one, it's barely visible, and two, it doesn't show what the other items you can get are, so that way you could see how to get them. The music is fine, and the graphics would probably be the thing that sticks out with Minecraft and Terraria. People would whine, "Minecraft is better cuz it haz 3D blox unliek Terraria which haz 2D old looking grafix LOL." TBH, I enjoy the graphics more than I did with Minecraft, because all Minecraft really has is blocks that can be used like Legos, so that isn't very original if you think about it. Nor is Terraria being original, but Terraria isn't being original in a better way Minecraft is. The one other thing, some people might say I have no skill for this, is that this game is actually pretty difficult. Skeletron and crew are all forces to be reckoned with. Eye of Cthulhu was always an extremely easy boss, same goes with King Slime, so they aren't part of this crew. The Twins, for me, personally were the hardest of all the bosses. Anyway, if you know me well, I love difficult games and is always willing to be challenged, so I enjoy this. Terarria isn't the greatest indie game of all time, but it would certainly make the top 10, maybe even the top 5.Graphics- 7.5/10Gameplay- 9/10Story- 3/10 (You really thought this game had much of a story?)Audio- 8/10Replayability- 9/10.:9.0/10:.+Challenging+Nice pixel graphics+Great gameplay+Interesting soundtrack+Fun bosses (Besides The Twins, gotta hate those two little cheapshots)-Odd crafting system-Too many NPCs, little use for many

content:
Posted: June 21, 2011
												Terraria is by far one of the best 2-D-survival, role-playing, side-scrolling games I have ever bought on Steam, and I've been playing it for 123 hours now.You can consider it to be a 2-D version of Minecraft, but despite Terraria's limitations in graphics, it has so much potential beyond MC.You can generate small, medium or large worlds; interesting, and almost seeming endless, exploration; online multiplayer; NPC's that move into your homes and you can buy stuff from them and/or sell it; infinite durability for tools and weapons; only losing your coins when you die; all the items you have for your own character get transferred; crafting potions and acquiring a numerous variety of weapons, clothing and other accessories; fighting challenging enemies and bosses; and so much more.The price may increase as more content is added, but overall, it has been the best $10 ever spent for a game so far.Full review: http://www.metacritic.com/user/TheThing2010Check my screenshots! :DUPDATE 11/23/16Even MORE content has been added to this game with Dungeon Defenders II content!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2011
												This game is epic for many reasons. For starters, people may buy this game because of its similarity to minecraft, but its much more deserving of that! Terraria has developers that not only keep in contact with its fans, but releases updates regularily (major content patch in ~1 week) and is still considered to be in "beta" stage, as it has so many paths it could follow.Sure, the game might have a small interest for re-playing as a new character, but as i said, its still a beta, and the Devs have confirmed they are working on that problem, this game will return every penny you spend tenfold, with its long game-span, as you start out a a noob and work up to Hell-stone gear. This can be as easy or as hard as you want it to be, with a large community and online resources and options to learn more / tweak the game to you're difficulty (coming soon in 1.0.5).Definate buy!!!<3, Leo :)

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												This game took me by surprise. I had heard it was similar to Mindcraft, except it was a side scrolling game. I actually found Terraria to be a lot of fun. You can explore underground tunnels, or create your own. Fight off a variety of monsters, collect treasure chests, harvest vines, trees etc. There are also quest areas where you can go into a dungeon, fight bosses and find exceptional loot. What I liked about this game most was probably how I could play with friends. Co-op play, travelling to different biomes and gathering new resources depending on what biome you are in, makes this game a challenge as well as rewarding. If you enjoyed minecraft, you may find this to your liking as well. The graphics are dumbed down, but it is done that way on purpose and gives the game a special charm. Pick this up if you don't have it in your library, I think you will really enjoy it.

Pour berry mixture into the crust, and dot with butter. Cut remaining pastry into 1/2 - 3/4 inch wide strips, and make lattice top. Crimp and flute edges.-Bake pie on lower shelf of oven for about 50 minutes, or until crust is golden brown.Tip:-Aluminum foil can be used to keep food moist, cook it evenly, and make clean-up easier.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2011
												As Terraria is my first sandbox, I will always look upon it fondly when I think of the genre. It will also be the standard from which I will judge other sandboxes, as it has offered so many hours of fun and exploration to me and my friends and family. It's quirky, silly, imaginative, and best of all, still growing.Story: 1/10"What the hell, Niko. This game is a sandbox- WHAT story?"As I'm reviewing Terraria against like-competitors such as Starbound and Edge of Space (both of which have some sort of story aspect), I felt the need to include this category to be fair. But yes- this is a sandbox. Stories are largely made by you, the player, even if the game has an almost-non-existent one.Gameplay: 10/10Terraria is a 2D game featuring humanoid-looking pixel characters that you can lightly-customize (hair and clothing color only) and choose the sex of. You can also choose to play in 3 different modes: Softcore, Mediumcore, and Hardcore, and 3 different world sizes: Large, Medium, and Small. Starting the game, you get a randomly-generated world and you find yourself standing next to the Guide (an NPC who is largely useless...), one of many NPCs you can attract into your base under the condition of proper accommodations and certain additional requirements. The game cycles through night and day, with night being particular dangerous to new players as it spawns much stronger monsters. Like other sandboxes, you gather raw materials to build a myriad of upgrades in armor, weapons, and tools. Unlike other sandboxes, Terraria features hundreds of different blocks and options for you to create the ultimate dream base and many different options for you to customize your appearance through armor and vanity items. There are bosses for the various stages of the game that you are at and some spawn at random. Additionally, events (both random and spawnable) occur in the world as you play it. Controls: 9/10You move/jump using the standard WASD/SPACE keys and interact with objects with your mouse. Combat is relatively smooth and mostly easy to navigate.Replayability: 10/10I have over 300 hours logged, so that already speaks for itself; in case it didn't: Terraria is a game that you pay for once (and for almost dirt cheap if you get it on sale) and it continues to get substantial updates AT NO COST to the players. Replayability is high, on this merit alone.Fun: 10/10The game has so many quirks between its bosses, building possibilities, and character customizations that you can't help but be drawn in to its world. Playing with friends means exploring together and sometimes, dying horrible deaths together (and grave markers won't let you forget it!)Conclusion:Terraria is love. Terraria is life.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Combining a fully destructible environment that you can rebuild to your liking with combat that will remind you of classic platformers of the past, this game is a must own!Although some people like to compare it to Minecraft because of the ability to build and craft things, Terraria is more focused on combat. Most of your resource gathering is going to be finding better metals and items so you can upgrade your weapons and armor (and this game has a ton of neat weapons and armor!) to take on even tougher monsters and bosses. Because of this, the real fun of the game is in the progression. Don't cheat yourself out of the experience by having a highly geared friend come along and give you top tier gear and rush you through the end game. Instead, convince them to re-roll a new character and start on a fresh world with you. Either of you can focus on a melee, magic, or ranged build of various types, so there's always plenty of replayability.Sadly, this replayability is somewhat finite. After defeating all of the bosses and getting top level items, there's not much left to do except building. And as I mentioned before, this isn't really the focus of the game. Still, Terraria is one of those games you will find yourself coming back to every few months to playAt the asking price of $9.99, Terraria is worth it, but it can often found on sale for $2.49. Snatch up a few copies at that price and pass them out to your friends! You'll all be glad you did!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Explore the darkest corners of your mind to build wonderful creations, and find out just how skillful you are with the well paced and beautifully designed boss battles. The perfect combination of a building game and an ARPG-Platformer. I think of Terraria as an upgraded Minecraft mixed with an upgraded Torchlight II. It is a wonderful experience that any gamer should have, or at least try out. Give it a go, you won't regret it!EDIT: this was written two years ago, and now I've come to play it for over 1000 hours, and I still get back to it from time to time, with the same impact and the same addictive gameplay that I know and love. The devs keep adding amazing content to it and the game never ends, you can play it forever and enjoy every minute of it. This is why I nominated Terraria for the "Test of Time" award.

content:

												This game, is a MASTER PIECE of video game technology, combining unlimited space exploration with the tradition zombie survival scenario that we see in such classics like "Donkey Kong 64" and "Diddy Kong Racing". PROS:+ cool gameplay+ creative concept of "build what you want"+ tons of crafting recipes+ appealing old-school graphics+ recent new content and multiplayer enhancement+ achievements are nicely designed to outline how to progressCONS:- the monster spawning mechanic is weird sometimes- a bit difficult for beginners to get the bulding concepts- couple of monster clipping issuesComment:A good game that will eat your time like there is no tomorrow! Comparison of gameplay with Minecraft is not wrong, however this game offers a bit more when it comes to combat. Multiplayer in it has been enhanced and is really the best way to play since interacting with your friends is great. I recommend it to anyone who likes to build stuff and has TONS of free time on their hands!

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												What can I say to do this game justice? I really like this game, from the countless hours I've enjoyed mining with the music changing depending on what biome/depth level I'm in. I've enjoyed creating blocking houses while looking on with envy at the screenshots of amazing buildings people have created. Killing some of the many bosses with abundant equipment drops. Getting my butt handed to me countless times. Falling to my death while constructing and generally derping off way more times than I care to admit.                                                                                                                                    I don't know, I just enjoy this game in it's entirety. From that moment when you find your first wooden boomarang,the moment you find your first spear, the moment when you dig straight into hell and fall into a pit of lava.                                                                                                                                                          There is always something new happening. Many bosses to kill and maim you untill you go full badass and womp em. Build your equipment up as a mage/fighter/ranged weapon user, or just combo everything! Armor sets that give you bonuses to everything from crit chances to mana and extra summons. I can totally understand how this game might not be for everyone but it has a style that just clicks with me. I whole heartedly recommend this game. Can you survive in this world and make it to hard mode? Or will you be crushed by the slimes and zombies?I've played this game off and on for a while recently been getting back into it, thought it'd be a good time to do a review.Not sure about the quality of my review though.Oh yes! NPC's build housing for you Npc's and you can start a village and get some people to set up shop! From simple Merchants to Gun salesmen! Make use of the guide if you don't know what to do/craft next show him an Item and he will show you what you need to finish an item Weapon/Armor/Trinkets/thingies.They have a hardcore mode if you wish to test yourself, with every map being randomized with equipment in chests and biomes tons of replayability.  You can also wear a bucket on your head.

												Terraria! Is it kinda like Minecraft? Well yeah, in the building way. 2D building blocks. That's all. However, compared to minecraft, Terraria is a more action packed game. Featuring many different bosses, weapons of all sorts... vanity items, and household items. All the different types of monsters (bosses included), different with each type of Biome. Jungles possess a hidden Temple, and sometimes you can find underground pyramids in your desert! If you like clothes, you have a plethora of vanity items to choose from to fully customize your character! And dyes to to color both your clothes... and house (via the painter)!All in all, its a really fun game you can play both offline and online. This game can be played in a very simple manner... or a complex way :)

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												  Absolutely enjoyable and addicting, Terraria succeeds in the cave/dungeon-style of gameplay. While there is no traditional experience bar or player skills, the vast quantity of gear in Terraria makes up for the inability to define your class stats wise. Boss battles are a MUST to progress, and the arena to fight them in, for the majority of them, are yours to create.A very important note: Play with friends.  Everything is better when friends are doing the same thing, and Terraria is no exception. A simple LAN connection between two or more friends can bring more enjoyment out of Terraria, not to mention helping out during a boss battle or escorting to retrieve your/their lost goods if you/they die.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												An all around great game, hundreds of hours hours of gameplay, good to play by your self or with a friend(or friends). Surprisingly difficult, but every victory is hard earned in this game. Plenty of opportunity for grand buildings, or dirt huts if that's what you prefer. A great variety of weapons to choose from. Want to play as a gun slinger, archer, or a swordsman? well you're in luck, all these are possible and many others as well, you can even mix and match if you want! Lots of memorable (occasionally hair pulling, and head to key board too) bosses that add a good challenge and a great sense of progression to the game. Being a 2-D, side scrolling, sandbox like game, it has a surprisingly large amount of content, definitely worth getting.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												It's a very good 2D platformer/adventure/RPG game, and cheap at that. Features creative enviroments along with unique and stylish NPCs, blocks, items, and more.     Terraria, The biggest sandbox game on steam (21 people on my friends list have it, just as proof), this game is very recommended from me. I've spent about 400+ hours into this game so far just from the past updates. With every update that comes along, me and my friends are always willing to brave this new patch and see what the troll developer Redigit has added this time that will make us "GAME WHAT THE FIDDLESTICKS". Terraria is full of funny and original ideas, it's nothing like minecraft if you want to get technical. Without going on to the wiki, you can enjoy and get immersed into the game much deeper without being told and just taking the steps down the road to endgame. Terraria is  VERY fun experience with friends, as we've created all new characters, and create maps for more than 10 times, where we go chugging through old challenges that we used to have difficulty with. Terraria in my opinion couldn't get old in a way where the games content is thick enough for anyone with freetime to enjoy in anyway.    THE CREATIVE ASPECT : (8.5/10) Yes, the game brings you with alot of ideas and motivations to build create and prosper a world, but without a freebuild system (Infinite supplies) in the game, it's hard to go try to start to build your great idea, but then run out of supplies to even begin to start building. Have the resources been dried up around your house? This forces you out of the safety radius and you have to obtain these supplies otherways. Chests around have blocks and bars which you can use to craft and build with and make things look beautiful. Giving this 8.5 on creative aspect because there is no freebuild is kind of hard, but yes. Your creation can come to life, with stuff inside there, like NPCs, and actual lights with switchs. You can make a mansion and it feels like your in GOD MOTHERmmmmmmmm HOTEL MARIO LIKE NPCS STOP OPENING THE DOORS    THE CHARACTER CREATION : (9/10) There are many possibilities you have to create a character that looks exactly like you. Now, part of the character creation is a part of the GAME game part of Terraria. You cannot choose your clothes in that menu. Items can be crafted, or found, however to better suit your needs. Tophats can be found during a slaughter of zombies and eyeballs trying to bring down your town or mansion with all their might. The other thing that kind of brings down this part of the game that there are alot of weird and (in my own opinion) unused haircuts that were added in a recent patch. They could've added better cuts, yes. It's not bad that they made these haircuts, they aren't trash but as their not the best thing in the window, you know?    THE GAME ITSELF : (10/10) The game itself is a wonderful masterpiece put together, besides all the collection items and haircuts and such. If you're good enough, you can skip the first boss and go face the next boss. Certain bosses you have to kill to progress so you can unlock the next place. The game doesn't use cheesy jokes either. In the dungeon, Skeletron can only be summoned at night, and The Wall of Flesh unlocks hardmode. There is a bit more but I dont want to fully spoil this for someone who hasn't played through hardmode yet. The platforming in the game is really spot on. Your jumps are wide and you have clear understanding where you're going to land. There is a knockback factor to this, where you have to do a little dodging and juking to avoid and kill the other stuff around you. In the progression part, NPCs are a really big help. The arms dealer sells a weapon that can make you do DRAMATIC difference of damage. The Merchant sells you basic needs and helps you along with housing and such. The dryad can help you remove corruption and crimson. Those are important in Terraria for you need housing to get NPCs, difference in damage is a smart idea to invest in when you're new to the game. if you wanna see skilled, look up Yrimir. He can probably help you go along in your journey.There's probably alot of mistakes, errors, and other ducks I didn't noticeTLDR Platforming Adventure where it's a combo of somewhat WoW, but also Mario.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Okay, this will be the first review I write, so like countless others have said, here we go:The game is wonderful, I have never encountered a bug in this game, and the reason being because the company that owns the game does such a beautiful job patching bugs and updating the game constantly (they're always adding new and exciting things!)The game play is extremely refreshing. There is something about the game play that reminds me of my wonderful times playing Cave Story, and god I love that game. It may be just me, but I can compare Terraria with Cave Story, and that's not a bad thing. Now, the art-style. All of my love, I find it so neat, and very cute!! (slimes!!!) (and countless other wild life I can go around capturing with my bug net which I then proceed to let free & flood my house full of birds and bugs!) I would like to add that in this game, you build, build, build. If that does not tickle your fancy, then you can wage war on the forces of evil at night, or fight beneath the surface (and even in the sky!) OR if still that does not suit you, then go out and explore your world which is randomly generated each time, so exploring is never a bore as the map is different each and every time! Choose between small, medium, and larger worlds accordingly to your tastes and jump in!And yet, even more~ you create your character before jumping into the world of Terraria, customize your character and name him/her whatever you'd like and set the difficulty of the game to what you'd like. Softcore is set up in a such a way that if you die, you lose all of your money (which you can still run back to and try to collect), medium, where you lose all money as well as items, and hard core, where your death is permanent! (Perfect for an all-nighter with friends!)Trying to stay alive is an adventure in this game, even death. Getting back to the loot you dropped when you died  is a quest and an adventure in and of itsself. Such is the world of Terrarria.BUT! You don't have to face the wrath of Terraria alone! Hop in with some friends and start slaying/crafting/building/catching/swimming/drowni- ARHGDR too many things! Too many gerunds!  Setting up a server for you and your friends is easy! The program to create your own server can be found within your Terraria folder. You can also choose to utilize other methods, if you desire.  Recently, one of my friends gifted Terraria to a friend who did not have it, so now the three of us are playing & exploring. Not to mention the time where we plunged to our deaths on a rope that was much too short, or that one time where we stepped on a preassure plate and activated a dart trap, and then proceeded to run around like chickens with their heads cut off, setting the trap off, again. (Luckily, none of us died. haha)I'm such a bad guide/reviewer that I was not able to go through EVERYTHING Terraria has to offer (Just too many things to talk about!). (Did I mention items you equip into your equipment slots show on your character?! OMG!!) but I decided that I have written enough, and because my word-count is probably higher than the word-count in my English class essays. (Maybe... Just... maybe... haha) Hopefully, I have at least enticed you into plunging into this beautiful, yet dangerous world.(I would like to add that I first bought this game on the console and only recently bought the PC version (YES! I bought the game twice!!), so the hours I have under my belt shown here are very deceiving numbers to my actual hours playing this game. The snails are so cute!!!)So, I think its high-time you discovered the millions of things I did not go through in my review. We are not born into this world "all-knowing", we must learn and then apply what we know.Welcome to the world, Terraria.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Terraria is a 2D co-op exploration and building game with dungeon crawling and hack and slash elements that makes for a really good time. I don't recommend playing this game alone as you won't find any enjoyment from mining up gear and fighting bosses when you don't have anyone to share that with, on the other hand once you have a friend or group of friends to experience Terraria with then you'll find it to be a highly interesting game.It's important to note that this isn't a deep game (In the figurative sense, literally it is actually pretty deep),  and you aren't going to find your self playing the game forever as eventually the game runs out of content. The worst thing I have to say about the game is that the experience can become a hollow experience eventually. The reason for this however is that it is an exploratory game by nature, and the less you know about it the better. By learning this game with your friends you'll find that it is a perfect way to spend upwards of a hundred hours cooperating across worlds to grow your knowledge and power.Lastly, don't compare this game to Minecraft, you won't get anywhere.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2013
												Terraria is a really nice game, although some may say "So much like Minecraft, just 2D" I say otherwise, this game has a LOT more than Minecraft without mods...World Genaration:The world genaration is pretty cool I guess, randomly makes a world at your picking of what size it is (small, medium or large) and then well if you want you could keep it or just make a new one, does not take that long.Character Customization:The character cuztomization is pretty simple aswel, as you can pick the colour of your character, male or female, and all those other things.Weapons: Heres where things get interesting, there are A LOT OF WEAPONS around over... 150ish and if you want to get them all you need to either craft them, find them, NPC's to get them.Armours: A lot of cool armours in the game, each armour gives you a buff if you have the entire set, such as a speed bost, or +2 armour points, but there are a lot more than that, and like the weapons, you craft them, find them and kill NPC's for them.NPC's:NPC mean Non-Playing Character, so basically AI (Artificial Intelligence). There are NPC's that will try to kill you (zombies, demon eyes, slimes, etc). And some that you need to make houses for to have them sell stuff with you and allow you to sell stuff to them, you unlock these NPC's in different ways, wether it be reaching a certain amount of money, finding a certain item, or killing a certain boss, and each NPC need a room to stay in, or else they will not move in, although you do start of with one.Tools:Most of the tools can be used as weapons, sometimes you need a certain "tier" of a tool to mine certain blocks, for example, you can't mine obsidian with a copper pickaxe. So you need to work towards getting better tools to help you get better armours and weapons.So all in all I do really like this game, as you can see bu how much I have played it. I hope you found this helpful, sorry if I have made any typos and have a nice day!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I never expected Terraria to be so addictive. Initially, upon purchase, I expected it to be some sort of 2D minecraft clone, where you just explore and build stuff. Never have I been so wrong. As you can see, at the time of this review, I have close to 400 hours in this game, which is more than any game I have ever played. Don't let the graphics of the game or the fact that the game is a 2D game throw you off. The graphics, while odd at first, eventually becomes so endearing you cannot imagine the game with any other graphics.Somehow, I can't place my finger on what makes the game so fun. It might be the sense of adventure as you journey through the underground in search of chests and loot. Or maybe it's the sense of thrill you get, fighting hordes of enemies while dangerously close to plunging to your death in lava. Or it could be due to the surprise you get, being blown up by explosives while peacefully exploring the caverns. The sense of relief and adrenaline as you narrowly escape death from enemies with just 6 health remaining, with your friends frantically trying to rescue you. Getting greedy as you spot a rare ore, only to be killed by a well placed trap. Overestimating yourself and trying to fight an enemy that slays you seconds later.There's always a sense of progression in this game, you get to fight increasingly tougher bosses, Yet it isn't forced, you can always play at your own pace. You can choose to rush through the game in order to get to the more challenging (and more fun) hardmode. Or you can take your time slowly exploring through the caves and jungles. Or you can choose to fish, getting load of great loot that way. The visual effects of the combat is absolutely stunning lategame, with so many unique weapons that you just want to try it all.Overall, this is a game I would highly recommend, great for playing with friends or just mucking about.ProsSense of adventureGreat co-opCool weapons lategameProgressionConsBoring in SingleplayerSteep learning curveNeed to rely on game wiki

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
PROS:+ cool gameplay+ creative concept of "build what you want"+ tons of crafting recipes+ appealing old-school graphics+ recent new content and multiplayer enhancement+ achievements are nicely designed to outline how to progressCONS:- the monster spawning mechanic is weird sometimes- a bit difficult for beginners to get the bulding concepts- couple of monster clipping issuesComment:A good game that will eat your time like there is no tomorrow! Comparison of gameplay with Minecraft is not wrong, however this game offers a bit more when it comes to combat. Multiplayer in it has been enhanced and is really the best way to play since interacting with your friends is great. I recommend it to anyone who likes to build stuff and has TONS of free time on their hands!

Posted: June 26, 2014
												A Truly pleasant and addictive game. Terraria it has a unique feel, as it perfectly mix the Building system into a RPG game. As you start playing, it's very easy to lose yourself in the game, because you don´t actually know what to do. But by the time you start building your home and workbench, you realize that the choices or armors, weapons and items you can craft are imense. But building and crafting is just a part of this game, you also can fight agains monsters and zombies and actually there are bosses with their own tactics. Combine this with the feeling of exploration and you have, in my opinion, a great game to enjoy it with your friends, or even, alone in your unique world. And also...watching four guys fully dedicated to decorate an house,it's something you wont see in any game.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												You may think, "PHOOEY I have heard about this sandbox block builder game and it sounds JUST LIKE MINECRAFT"   well its not, with delightfully fun graphics and well made controls. Terraria is easy to learn, has several bosses and over 1,000 items to make or find.But okay, you want to hear the BAD stuff, well there are a few things that you should know, the characters and items are quite small compared to the screen, The world size can be chosen at the start but the worlds are not infinite, Servers are hard to set up or join, and while most of the bosses are  very fun, the last three require a lot of grinding for materials before you can beat them. But other than those few things, its a GREAT GAME.so if you are considering getting it, I would say that if you think you'll like it, you'll like it. so go ahead build anything, the non infinite terraria sky is the limit!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												An incredibly fun game! Would definitely recommend! I *forced* my friend to buy the game. She was doubtful at first, but she loves the game now!Biomes: The game has very many different biomes, so it's much to explore! They all have an interesting look, their own different monsters and its own music soundtrack. Awesome!Monsters: There are tons of different monsters in the game! They all have nice designs, and drop different items. Cool!Bosses: The bosses have very epic designs, like so epic you go "Wow" when you see it! They have cool background music and their own combat style. I love the bosses very much!Items: There are almost 3000 items in the game! That is A LOT! There are many weapons to choose from, as swords, bows, guns, throwing, boomerang, spears, staffs, spelltomes, yoyos... There is also very much different armor to choose from. They can benefit your damage, mobility, meelee speed, health regen, and much more. They have cool designs too, and if that's not enough already, you can also dye them with colors to make them look cooler. There are also accessories, which benefit different things.Building: With very many blocks to choose from, and so many variations of furniture, and cool decorations, the combinations are nearly endless! You can also paint the walls and blocks with many different colors to increase the possibilities even more!You can set your house wherever you feel like; on the ground, in the air, on an flying island, in a cave, in the lake, even in hell, if you so feel like it.In Terraria there are so many things to do. So much exploring, many items to find, bosses to slay, and houses to build. It takes very long to do all the things in Terraria, which I like, so that you never really get bored with new stuff to do all the time. You can play with friends to make it 10x as fun. If the game is too easy for you, which I doubt it is, there is Expert mode!Tl;dr: Get Terraria. I rate 10/10.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												My absolute favourite game. The fact it becomes many, many times more enjoyable with somebody you care about cannot be understated. Play it with a family member, a loved one or a close friend - or many!THE hands down best games on steam for those who more than two of:2D gamesPlatformersFighting gamesCraftingBuildingShootingGrappling hooksMultiplayer coopRPG gamesOpen woldProcedural world generationNon-linear gameplay (create your own story)Boss fightsBOSS FIGHTSBOSS LOOTSO many ITEMSSO much to CRAFTCasual gameplayHardcore gameplayExpert modeStill here?FREQUENT UPDATES, 5 YEARS after its releaseModding capabilitiesController supportLAN playOffline playAMAZING soundtrackThings Terraria DOESNT have:Game-breaking bugsSplit-screenA story mode (the game has a strength-based progression though - you wont be able to defeat the stronger enemies without crafting or finding better gear, which sets you up for a "level" system completely based on your own skill, and of course luck.Endless worlds. They are created before you enter them, so they DO have a finite size. They are usually very large, though.Recommendations: Find a good friend/girlfriend/boyfriend/sibling/parent or three to play with this. Learning the game is the most fun part of the experience, and that experience is not only best shared - it makes getting the hang of things a lot easier, as well as exploring a lot more fun.You like roleplaying? Terraria is good for that.You like not dying? Better get ready to play your extreme best, in that case. This is the dark souls of 2D games.go buy it. It's not just worth it on a sale - the game is worth buying for the price of its 4-pack!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												It's time for my first review. To me personally,Terraria is the first game that came to mind. This game has so much to offer. The art style is wonderful, and I prefer it over any 3D game like Minecraft. The flat perspective by all means does not take away from the gameplay in the least. The controls are super simple and is a great starter for a large range of ages. Crafting sometimes becomes complicated, but with the guide it's not that big of an issue at all, and even though the wiki isn't entirely complete it helps solve most of the questions about that. The fact that the world has a huge range of different biomes to explore really keeps the game interesting. With the randomization of worlds when they are created as well, it's another interesting feature that not everyone will end up with the same items, and it takes multiple world explorations to get specific items. I definitely recommend softcore difficulty to begin with, however. Playing Terraria like one would play Minecraft can cause a lot of trouble and frustration that can take away from your experience as you reach a halt in your progress. It's similar to Pokemon. Beat it first, then do a Nuzlocke replay.The only complaint I have with the game is the hassle it is trying to get the multiplayer to work. There have been several occasions where it's taken hours to get the connection to work, and sometimes even then we call it quits before we can get the server up. When the multiplayer does work, however, it really is a great time and spices up the gameplay. I just wish it wasn't so frustrating to work sometimes.Overall this game is absolutely fantastic and will remain one of my staple games for blowing freetime and having fun with my friends for a long, long time. 9/10.

Terraria is a survival-type 2D game where you build houses, mine, explore, and fight epic bosses. You can also play with friends for more awesomeness. So much content and a playthrough takes about 30 hours. (EDIT: With recent updates a playthrough is more like 50-100 hours) Totally recommend it to anyone who likes adventure/fighting/survival/2D games.And one other thing, this game has no resemblance to Minecraft. The only things that are similar is that you have a pickaxe, an axe, dirt blocks, irone ore, and stone... but other than that it is incredibly unique! It truly is a great game and has given me literally 100s of hours of enjoyment.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												Looking for an Indie game with a lot of fun? Terraria's for you.It somewhat lacks logic, bo I guess this is its main charm and why it makes that so good.Freedom to pick your own playstyle as well as choose between classes, but you're not completely restricted to them.Huge variety of weaponry, armors, accesories, many mobs, mounts, everything you need to fight all these huge amounts of mobs or bosses.Every playthrough yields different experience, so you don't get bored too easily.Also you can be mainly a builder type and believe me, you are able to build beautiful things in this game, if you're skilled and patient enough. Pixel art is in option too.And in contrary to popular belief, Terraria IS NOT like, nor a copy of Minecraft. Justifying it by saying "these are games with blocks and building" is a complete nonsense overused by kids, since there's Trove with really high votes and people don't complain.Both differ in many aspects, the first one goes far, far away from the latter, most notably with its fighting system or countless amounts of different mobs, overall graphics and its theme. Only RNGesus may troll you sometimes, but guess that's how this system works, after all.Either playing alone, making some runs or just for fun with friends, this is an amazing game. You can spend hundreds of hours and you still won't be able to complete it in 100%.I definitely recommend to buy it for those who consider it. Worth spending money and it's quite often on sales.Oh and by the way, don't get swarmed by ridiculousness of this game.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												It's like taking Minecraft and showering it with creativity. Terraria succeeds where Minecraft fails by adapating crafting and mining elements and mixing them with what a gamer would want to play with. Swords of the earth, katanas, magic water wands, space guns, and even a variation of lightsabers! This is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to what this game has to offer, as the bosses are creative with each being unique in its own right. The story is left for you to uncover and you are able to choose how you want to advance through the game at your own pace. The developers really take advantage of the side-scrolling perspective of the game and blend it together with concepts that could only be achieved with Terraria. And if you ever get bored of the traditional experience, there's multiplayer, servers, mods, and modded multiplayer! While it doesn't have a definitive "creative mode", fan-software such as tEdit easily compensate and work smoothly.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												    A lot of people will say this game is just like 2D Minecraft. The thing is, most of those people have less than an hour on record of this game. The only reason this could be compared to Minecraft is that it has blocks. That's it. Minecraft is a great game, but it and Terraria are two different things. Terraria has hundreds more items to explore and craft, more enemies and bosses to fight and earn rewards, more underground places to explore, and overall more of a sense of true adventure rather than just a sandbox/survival game. It can be confusing at times, but that's why they give you a guide at the beginning! Also, the Terraria wiki has everything you could possibly want to know about the game. Overall this game is amazing and fun, especially with the new 1.3 update! I totally recommend this game!   (Also, many people complain that they thought Mac support would be added in 1.3 and say that their money is "wasted." The problem is, right under the game screen it says right there what you need to have to play this game. Just read the requirements BEFORE you buy the game so no money is wasted.)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												It's time for my first review. To me personally,Terraria is the first game that came to mind. This game has so much to offer. The art style is wonderful, and I prefer it over any 3D game like Minecraft. The flat perspective by all means does not take away from the gameplay in the least. The controls are super simple and is a great starter for a large range of ages. Crafting sometimes becomes complicated, but with the guide it's not that big of an issue at all, and even though the wiki isn't entirely complete it helps solve most of the questions about that. The fact that the world has a huge range of different biomes to explore really keeps the game interesting. With the randomization of worlds when they are created as well, it's another interesting feature that not everyone will end up with the same items, and it takes multiple world explorations to get specific items. I definitely recommend softcore difficulty to begin with, however. Playing Terraria like one would play Minecraft can cause a lot of trouble and frustration that can take away from your experience as you reach a halt in your progress. It's similar to Pokemon. Beat it first, then do a Nuzlocke replay.The only complaint I have with the game is the hassle it is trying to get the multiplayer to work. There have been several occasions where it's taken hours to get the connection to work, and sometimes even then we call it quits before we can get the server up. When the multiplayer does work, however, it really is a great time and spices up the gameplay. I just wish it wasn't so frustrating to work sometimes.Overall this game is absolutely fantastic and will remain one of my staple games for blowing freetime and having fun with my friends for a long, long time. 9/10.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Terraria is a 2D co-op exploration and building game with dungeon crawling and hack and slash elements that makes for a really good time. I don't recommend playing this game alone as you won't find any enjoyment from mining up gear and fighting bosses when you don't have anyone to share that with, on the other hand once you have a friend or group of friends to experience Terraria with then you'll find it to be a highly interesting game.It's important to note that this isn't a deep game (In the figurative sense, literally it is actually pretty deep),  and you aren't going to find your self playing the game forever as eventually the game runs out of content. The worst thing I have to say about the game is that the experience can become a hollow experience eventually. The reason for this however is that it is an exploratory game by nature, and the less you know about it the better. By learning this game with your friends you'll find that it is a perfect way to spend upwards of a hundred hours cooperating across worlds to grow your knowledge and power.Lastly, don't compare this game to Minecraft, you won't get anywhere.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Over the course of the past 3 years, I have come to respect this game greatly.It isn't just a simple minecraft clone, 'nor is it just some platformer with the ability to build.It's much more than that, it's a world filled with creativity, terror, friendly characters, monsters, caves, labyrinths, a plethora of weapons, and whatever sized dirt house you want to make (just so long as it's below 8400 X 2400 blocks).The game starts off fairly simple, with relatively intuitive gameplay for a new user (tools work much like they do in most sandbox games) and a few simple slimey things that you can hit with your sword.After some time you get better at killing the Slimes, have built your hole of dirt in the ground, and feel like there must be more to this game. So you explore.Whether you explore vertically by tunneling and going through caves, or walking through the landscape above, you're bound to run into some sort of enemy problem.You die in some grotesque manner with lots of blood involved and respawn back where you first started (unless you're a god and somehow get to the end of the game without dying). And so the thrill of exploring begins again! With more dying involved!Over time you get stronger and stronger as you find yourself exploring more of the world you're in. You pick up magical items and build mansions (or more dirt houses) for your townspeople to live in. You kill a few bosses, outline your class (mage, ranged, warrior, summoner), find some cool looking places and destroy everything that lives inside them.Then you slowly tunnel into the Underworld, which is pretty much Hell. You get even better equipment and learn that you can make the game harder by beating  yet another boss. So you go for it and eventually beat the poop out of it.Then you die.And die again.And probably die a few more times until you actually get even better equipment(!!)Through this you unlock:More bosses to killMore enemies to slaughterMore amazing weapons and accessories to build and equipMore bosses, enemies, wepaons, etc, etc, etc.Until you finally have come to the end-game. You always had the option to do whatever you wanted to do, you could have used this as a farming simulator and brewed potions for fun. But instead you went ahead and decided to achieve an amazing feat. All thanks to you having picked up this masterpiece.Well done.

												Terraria is arguably the greatest and most unique 2D sandbox platformer out there. Its combination of typical sandbox elements with unforgiving RPG progression provides both incentive and reward. The amount of content is perfect even before mods, and the progression is satisfying as the player upgrades to each tier and defeats each boss. Some people claim that it's basically minecraft. It isn't. It's an RPG and a platformer, with a unique art style and unique mechanics. Minecraft is a 3D sandbox with little progression which focuses on the user's willingness to build structures and devices, and while this is possible in Terraria, is by no means the main aim of the game.All in all, an amazing 2D platformer with both sandbox and RPG elements unlike any other out there, promising hours and hours of fun.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I avoided Terraria for a while on the basis that it looked like a sidescrolling Minecraft. I'm glad someone talked me into giving it a try.It's true that you mine, craft, and build with blocks like so many other games but this one cuts all the excess wandering around and leaves only the fun stuff. It gives you the freedom to do absolutely nothing while encouraging you to explore by rewarding you for searching out special boss enemies and exploring the world.I equated it to other block-based building games just because it had block units. After I gave it a chance I'm glad to say it feels much more completed and unique than other similar games. If you're a fan of sidescrolling adventure games or creative sandbox games, I'd highly recommend giving Terraria a try.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												It's a very good 2D platformer/adventure/RPG game, and cheap at that. Features creative enviroments along with unique and stylish NPCs, blocks, items, and more.     Terraria, The biggest sandbox game on steam (21 people on my friends list have it, just as proof), this game is very recommended from me. I've spent about 400+ hours into this game so far just from the past updates. With every update that comes along, me and my friends are always willing to brave this new patch and see what the troll developer Redigit has added this time that will make us "GAME WHAT THE FIDDLESTICKS". Terraria is full of funny and original ideas, it's nothing like minecraft if you want to get technical. Without going on to the wiki, you can enjoy and get immersed into the game much deeper without being told and just taking the steps down the road to endgame. Terraria is  VERY fun experience with friends, as we've created all new characters, and create maps for more than 10 times, where we go chugging through old challenges that we used to have difficulty with. Terraria in my opinion couldn't get old in a way where the games content is thick enough for anyone with freetime to enjoy in anyway.    THE CREATIVE ASPECT : (8.5/10) Yes, the game brings you with alot of ideas and motivations to build create and prosper a world, but without a freebuild system (Infinite supplies) in the game, it's hard to go try to start to build your great idea, but then run out of supplies to even begin to start building. Have the resources been dried up around your house? This forces you out of the safety radius and you have to obtain these supplies otherways. Chests around have blocks and bars which you can use to craft and build with and make things look beautiful. Giving this 8.5 on creative aspect because there is no freebuild is kind of hard, but yes. Your creation can come to life, with stuff inside there, like NPCs, and actual lights with switchs. You can make a mansion and it feels like your in GOD MOTHERmmmmmmmm HOTEL MARIO LIKE NPCS STOP OPENING THE DOORS    THE CHARACTER CREATION : (9/10) There are many possibilities you have to create a character that looks exactly like you. Now, part of the character creation is a part of the GAME game part of Terraria. You cannot choose your clothes in that menu. Items can be crafted, or found, however to better suit your needs. Tophats can be found during a slaughter of zombies and eyeballs trying to bring down your town or mansion with all their might. The other thing that kind of brings down this part of the game that there are alot of weird and (in my own opinion) unused haircuts that were added in a recent patch. They could've added better cuts, yes. It's not bad that they made these haircuts, they aren't trash but as their not the best thing in the window, you know?    THE GAME ITSELF : (10/10) The game itself is a wonderful masterpiece put together, besides all the collection items and haircuts and such. If you're good enough, you can skip the first boss and go face the next boss. Certain bosses you have to kill to progress so you can unlock the next place. The game doesn't use cheesy jokes either. In the dungeon, Skeletron can only be summoned at night, and The Wall of Flesh unlocks hardmode. There is a bit more but I dont want to fully spoil this for someone who hasn't played through hardmode yet. The platforming in the game is really spot on. Your jumps are wide and you have clear understanding where you're going to land. There is a knockback factor to this, where you have to do a little dodging and juking to avoid and kill the other stuff around you. In the progression part, NPCs are a really big help. The arms dealer sells a weapon that can make you do DRAMATIC difference of damage. The Merchant sells you basic needs and helps you along with housing and such. The dryad can help you remove corruption and crimson. Those are important in Terraria for you need housing to get NPCs, difference in damage is a smart idea to invest in when you're new to the game. if you wanna see skilled, look up Yrimir. He can probably help you go along in your journey.There's probably alot of mistakes, errors, and other ducks I didn't noticeTLDR Platforming Adventure where it's a combo of somewhat WoW, but also Mario.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2011
												Inspired by Lockean philosophy, Terraria draws heavily from Chapter V of John Locke's Second Treatise of Government. The game's map creator alludes to a God-like being who first creates the world then populates it with humans. Everyone within is then given the world "for the support and comfort of their being" (or "character," in the game's context). However, if the world belongs to everyone, how can we appropriate its resources for particular individuals to make use of them? In Terraria, a player via the character can extract the natural resources from the land and its wild creatures, which initially belonged to all, and mix their own labor with the natural resources to create something unique; this created product then belongs to the character due to the labor placed within it. The game mechanics follow Locke's original law of nature rather closely; they do an amateur but lovely job educating on the state of nature envisioned in the Treatise.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												Best game in its genre.Often compared to Minecraft, and that may be somewhat true, in that there is crafting from materials gathered from the game world, however, Terraria is a lot more action orientated. And in my opinion, a heck of a lot more fun.There is fantastic progression of challenges and equipment. Really intense and fun boss fights. Hundreds of interesting and quirky items. Everything from the music, to the animations is just pure excellence.On top of all these amazing qualities, the developers are some of the most generous devs I've ever seen. Since Terraria was officially released, they have released two massive content patches (1.1 and 1.2) that added more content than most games would include in a full expansion. Content patch 1.3 is around the corner and hints at even more content, all included in the original purchase of the game.I can't rate this game any higher, it is truly excellent and has so much charm. Definitely pick it up if you are on the fence.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Has the same "just one more block" addictiveness as Minecraft.A lot of people compare Terraria to Minecraft. Minecraft (in 3D) focuses more on creative aspects, with some character advancement. Terraria (in 2D) focuses more on RPG/character progression aspects, with plenty of creative opportunities. Minecraft has more generated content, while Terraria has more hand-crafted content. Minecraft has fewer unique items, fewer varieties of monsters, etc. Terraria has more variety, but is limited to 2 dimensions.In multiplayer with a fair number of players, a world quickly becomes swiss cheese; riddled with holes. There is limited space, and limited resources. The server I play on has a mod that places more statues and treasure chests over time so that there's always new loot. By comparison, Minecraft doesn't suffer from this problem because (a) it has an infinitely-large world, and (b) it's in 3 dimensions.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2012
												My initial evaluation of Terraria was: "It's the poor man's Minecraft."After a bunch of hours playing both titles, I've concluded that Terraria's more fun as well.I've never seen a game with the same level of love and dedication from its developers.  With each version patch comes an incredible amount of new content - always completely free of charge - that gives new life to the game, and keeps Terraria fun to play even years after buying it.I can't explain why doing something so monotonous is so fun.  It's not even like the monotony of leveling in an MMO because there's no leveling in Terraria.  It's just digging, killing, and building (with an x1000 on the digging part).  But it works.  It's a blast, and you should own it.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Terraria is a fantastic mix of Metroidvania-style exploration and combat, lego building and a random number generator.You can generate worlds from small to large and harvest ore, wood and other resources to build your dream home. You can also upgrade your equipment and use it to battle numerous enemies and bosses that populate your world.The sky's the limit! No wait, space is the limit. Build your home in space!At any rate, there's a lot of variety and freedom to do whatever you want.Of course, there are caveats. People who prefer a game with more direction might not appreciate Terraria, as it can be easy to get lost in it and be uncertain how to progress. The endgame can be pretty unforgiving too as the sloppy combat makes it difficult to dodge bosses and said bosses often rely on a lot of projectiles and high stats to get the job done.But these are minor smudges on an otherwise amazing game.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												You may think, "PHOOEY I have heard about this sandbox block builder game and it sounds JUST LIKE MINECRAFT"   well its not, with delightfully fun graphics and well made controls. Terraria is easy to learn, has several bosses and over 1,000 items to make or find.But okay, you want to hear the BAD stuff, well there are a few things that you should know, the characters and items are quite small compared to the screen, The world size can be chosen at the start but the worlds are not infinite, Servers are hard to set up or join, and while most of the bosses are  very fun, the last three require a lot of grinding for materials before you can beat them. But other than those few things, its a GREAT GAME.so if you are considering getting it, I would say that if you think you'll like it, you'll like it. so go ahead build anything, the non infinite terraria sky is the limit!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												It's like taking Minecraft and showering it with creativity. Terraria succeeds where Minecraft fails by adapating crafting and mining elements and mixing them with what a gamer would want to play with. Swords of the earth, katanas, magic water wands, space guns, and even a variation of lightsabers! This is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to what this game has to offer, as the bosses are creative with each being unique in its own right. The story is left for you to uncover and you are able to choose how you want to advance through the game at your own pace. The developers really take advantage of the side-scrolling perspective of the game and blend it together with concepts that could only be achieved with Terraria. And if you ever get bored of the traditional experience, there's multiplayer, servers, mods, and modded multiplayer! While it doesn't have a definitive "creative mode", fan-software such as tEdit easily compensate and work smoothly.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												    A lot of people will say this game is just like 2D Minecraft. The thing is, most of those people have less than an hour on record of this game. The only reason this could be compared to Minecraft is that it has blocks. That's it. Minecraft is a great game, but it and Terraria are two different things. Terraria has hundreds more items to explore and craft, more enemies and bosses to fight and earn rewards, more underground places to explore, and overall more of a sense of true adventure rather than just a sandbox/survival game. It can be confusing at times, but that's why they give you a guide at the beginning! Also, the Terraria wiki has everything you could possibly want to know about the game. Overall this game is amazing and fun, especially with the new 1.3 update! I totally recommend this game!   (Also, many people complain that they thought Mac support would be added in 1.3 and say that their money is "wasted." The problem is, right under the game screen it says right there what you need to have to play this game. Just read the requirements BEFORE you buy the game so no money is wasted.)

												Okay, So how to Rate my Favourite game of all time with out Over Exceeding?Eh' just Review it i guess. Terraria Review Terraria Is a very VERY fun Sand-box/RPG-Styled Game Progression is fun, Not overly diffuclt On The normal diffuctly. Not Kazio Over-load Like most game's "Expert" Easy to host, Not too laggy.Heaps of content. But Most important of all Shape your Worlds and Characters to Your heart's Desires, Your character is YOUR Character. Your world is YOUR world. Make lore for it, You want your character to be a Pit fiend? So be it. Core Features Status Effects, Health, Mana, Ammo, Defence, Mining, Placing, Damage,Bosses,Events
Each speaks  for  it's self. Building/CharactersBuilding is simple, And really rewarding and feels like an achivment.
Build what you wish -- A Tower? Sure, A giant Floating island? Sure.
Whatever you wish! 

Characters are a bit harder to customize (No Dye Flipping )
But still very much customizeable
Also Pay no Attention to the community, Ever.They are all Either Hacking Noobs that are of The age 6 - 12 yr olds Who aren't supposed to be playing this game, and Don't accept anything from them.Aside from this the game is Perfect.Heaps of content to explore.Over all Rating10/10 (Actually Truthful here for me)Would give these Devs 200$ For free.Updated reviewNominated This game as Custom reward "My Favourite game" Reward

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												My absolute favourite game. The fact it becomes many, many times more enjoyable with somebody you care about cannot be understated. Play it with a family member, a loved one or a close friend - or many!THE hands down best games on steam for those who more than two of:2D gamesPlatformersFighting gamesCraftingBuildingShootingGrappling hooksMultiplayer coopRPG gamesOpen woldProcedural world generationNon-linear gameplay (create your own story)Boss fightsBOSS FIGHTSBOSS LOOTSO many ITEMSSO much to CRAFTCasual gameplayHardcore gameplayExpert modeStill here?FREQUENT UPDATES, 5 YEARS after its releaseModding capabilitiesController supportLAN playOffline playAMAZING soundtrackThings Terraria DOESNT have:Game-breaking bugsSplit-screenA story mode (the game has a strength-based progression though - you wont be able to defeat the stronger enemies without crafting or finding better gear, which sets you up for a "level" system completely based on your own skill, and of course luck.Endless worlds. They are created before you enter them, so they DO have a finite size. They are usually very large, though.Recommendations: Find a good friend/girlfriend/boyfriend/sibling/parent or three to play with this. Learning the game is the most fun part of the experience, and that experience is not only best shared - it makes getting the hang of things a lot easier, as well as exploring a lot more fun.You like roleplaying? Terraria is good for that.You like not dying? Better get ready to play your extreme best, in that case. This is the dark souls of 2D games.go buy it. It's not just worth it on a sale - the game is worth buying for the price of its 4-pack!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												It's time for my first review. To me personally,Terraria is the first game that came to mind. This game has so much to offer. The art style is wonderful, and I prefer it over any 3D game like Minecraft. The flat perspective by all means does not take away from the gameplay in the least. The controls are super simple and is a great starter for a large range of ages. Crafting sometimes becomes complicated, but with the guide it's not that big of an issue at all, and even though the wiki isn't entirely complete it helps solve most of the questions about that. The fact that the world has a huge range of different biomes to explore really keeps the game interesting. With the randomization of worlds when they are created as well, it's another interesting feature that not everyone will end up with the same items, and it takes multiple world explorations to get specific items. I definitely recommend softcore difficulty to begin with, however. Playing Terraria like one would play Minecraft can cause a lot of trouble and frustration that can take away from your experience as you reach a halt in your progress. It's similar to Pokemon. Beat it first, then do a Nuzlocke replay.The only complaint I have with the game is the hassle it is trying to get the multiplayer to work. There have been several occasions where it's taken hours to get the connection to work, and sometimes even then we call it quits before we can get the server up. When the multiplayer does work, however, it really is a great time and spices up the gameplay. I just wish it wasn't so frustrating to work sometimes.Overall this game is absolutely fantastic and will remain one of my staple games for blowing freetime and having fun with my friends for a long, long time. 9/10.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Terraria! Is it kinda like Minecraft? Well yeah, in the building way. 2D building blocks. That's all. However, compared to minecraft, Terraria is a more action packed game. Featuring many different bosses, weapons of all sorts... vanity items, and household items. All the different types of monsters (bosses included), different with each type of Biome. Jungles possess a hidden Temple, and sometimes you can find underground pyramids in your desert! If you like clothes, you have a plethora of vanity items to choose from to fully customize your character! And dyes to to color both your clothes... and house (via the painter)!All in all, its a really fun game you can play both offline and online. This game can be played in a very simple manner... or a complex way :)

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Over the course of the past 3 years, I have come to respect this game greatly.It isn't just a simple minecraft clone, 'nor is it just some platformer with the ability to build.It's much more than that, it's a world filled with creativity, terror, friendly characters, monsters, caves, labyrinths, a plethora of weapons, and whatever sized dirt house you want to make (just so long as it's below 8400 X 2400 blocks).The game starts off fairly simple, with relatively intuitive gameplay for a new user (tools work much like they do in most sandbox games) and a few simple slimey things that you can hit with your sword.After some time you get better at killing the Slimes, have built your hole of dirt in the ground, and feel like there must be more to this game. So you explore.Whether you explore vertically by tunneling and going through caves, or walking through the landscape above, you're bound to run into some sort of enemy problem.You die in some grotesque manner with lots of blood involved and respawn back where you first started (unless you're a god and somehow get to the end of the game without dying). And so the thrill of exploring begins again! With more dying involved!Over time you get stronger and stronger as you find yourself exploring more of the world you're in. You pick up magical items and build mansions (or more dirt houses) for your townspeople to live in. You kill a few bosses, outline your class (mage, ranged, warrior, summoner), find some cool looking places and destroy everything that lives inside them.Then you slowly tunnel into the Underworld, which is pretty much Hell. You get even better equipment and learn that you can make the game harder by beating  yet another boss. So you go for it and eventually beat the poop out of it.Then you die.And die again.And probably die a few more times until you actually get even better equipment(!!)Through this you unlock:More bosses to killMore enemies to slaughterMore amazing weapons and accessories to build and equipMore bosses, enemies, wepaons, etc, etc, etc.Until you finally have come to the end-game. You always had the option to do whatever you wanted to do, you could have used this as a farming simulator and brewed potions for fun. But instead you went ahead and decided to achieve an amazing feat. All thanks to you having picked up this masterpiece.Well done.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												This is a nice game, is worth the buy. There is something for almost everyone: If you like to mine, you can mine; if you cant to build, you can build; if you want to fish, you can fish; if you want to explore, you can explore; and best of all, if you like to FIGHT, you can FIGHT!Pros:-Like I said, big variety of activities to do in this game.-You'll love this game if you both are solo or with friends.-The game is so big, you will have to spend hours and hours to have the best loadout.-PVP mode funny and you get a lot of laughs playing it with your friends.-Easy to make a server and host it to play with your friends.-Mods made by community are aviable, no supported by Terraria's developers though.Cons:-You'll need to check a wiki about this game a lot of times, because there is no more guide from the game than the first NPC Guide.-Maybe mine is very useless, you can get better equipment killing bosses and looking for chests, and mining is not worth at all.-The Corruption/Crimson and the Hallow are very overpowered, they become annoying and its hard to stop/remove them.-Not very good traductions, but this is acceptable though.Final: This is a 'worth-the-money' game, it brings you a lot of hours of intense gameplay, and/or funny moments playing it with your friends. I love it and their developers are doing from it a very good game with every update, what is unexpected in the most games nowadays. And Im waiting for Terraria 2, I think I would instabuy it.PD: Sorry if I had some mistakes, Im not from USA/Britain.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
Terraria ReviewInformation About the GameTerrarai is a 2D platform game in which you create a custom character and enter your own world which can either be small, medium or large. Think mine craft but 2D, you go out an explore and then build, with occasional enemies and bosses to fight along the way.The ReviewI started playing Terraria when a friend told me its a must have game and something to do while the sever we played on was down, when I first got the game I didn't think much of it because everything was either done or I didn't have the equipment to do anything but things changed when I started my own server and explored the world and read all the wiki links(http://terraria.wikia.com/wiki/Terraria_Wiki) on how to build and make euipment. People say Terraira is only fun when your on with friends but in my opinion the games is fun to the extent of you own imagination regardless of friends playing or not. The enemies and bosses can sometimes be a bit overpowered and annoying when your are truing to build and constantly being hit by pixies or the overpowered pinks ones with laser beams.The RatingI would say yes Terraria is a fantastic game even with the new updates but it dose get a bit repetitive if you constantly killing pixies over and over and over again so this does hurt the game a lot and wish for when Terraria 2 comes out that the problem will be dealt with. So in sum Terraria needs a few more things adding to make it one of the greats hopefully Terraria 2 will fix this.Thanks for reading Cash

content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
												Its worth paying for. Terraria is a wide game if you give the time for it.I think many people who have JUST heard of Terraria may think its a Minecraft but 2D. Some of them are right, but are also wrong too.The Plot:I wouldn't really say a plot is in Terraria. How i would put it is like this:You arrived in a land, alien to what it normally is, around you is wood, water, a man, and varoius landscapes. Your move.Gameplay:This is the games beef. All the weapons and gear you find is intresting. some of them refrence games, like Pixel Piracy. some armor and vanity wear does too. The building in Terraria is also a great aspect. adding minecarts, and wire for electricity. You can nearly build anything you want. In 2D of course.Graphically it does not shine honestly, but graphics are not everything to a game. But honestly, the combat is solid, yeah its point and click but it feels so satisfying when you swing your sword and the guts of a zombie fly away. The Bosses do prove a challenge to the new player. I mean when I fought the Eye of Cthulhu yeah i was like: "OH GOD WHAT DO I DO!?" but then the first few bosses do teach you to use what you got honestly. If you play A Link to Terraria, which honestly is a great map if you like Zelda and Terraria. But back to the game.Protecting your land is a important part if you want to keep your NPC's safe too, since there are invasion battles like the goblin army. I personally take it as an endurance round. Cause thats what it basically is.Overall, if i had to rate Terraria. it would be a 9/10I'll re-edit this for 1.3! :D
